member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1
member.summary: Specifies the methods that must be implemented by a class to support T-precision real LAPACK routines for general matrices.

remarks.para: The Linear Algebra PACKage (LAPACK) is the de facto standard for more complex linear algebra problems. It complements the Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines (BLAS), which defines standards for low level vector and matrix operations.

member.param: A value that specifies which part of the matrix to copy.
The number of rows of the matrix.
The number of columns of the matrix.
An array containing the elements of the source matrix.
Offset into of the first element of the source matrix.
Distance between the first element of the columns of the source matrix in the array .
An array containing the elements of the destination matrix.
Offset into of the first element of the destination matrix.
Distance between the first element of the columns of the destination matrix in the array .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Getrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
Computes an LU decomposition of a general M-by-N matrix A using partial pivoting with row interchanges.
The decomposition has the form
A = P * L * U
where P is a permutation matrix, L is lower triangular with unit diagonal elements (lower trapezoidal if m > n), and U is upper triangular (upper trapezoidal if m < n).
This is the right-looking Level 3 BLAS version of the algorithm.
member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
Array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length min(,) that will hold the pivot indexes. Row i of the matrix was interchanged with row [i].

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Getrs(Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Solves a system of linear equations using the LU decomposition computed by .

remarks.para: The system has the form

para.center: A * X = B or A' * X = B

remarks.para: where A is a square matrix.

member.param: A value that specifies the form of the system of equations.
An integer specifying the number of rows and columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of right-hand sides. Must be greater than or equal to zero.
Array that contains the elements of the LU decomposition computed by .
Offset into of the first element of the LU decomposition.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length that holds the pivot indexes computed by .
An array containing the elements of the right-hand side.
Offset into of the first element of the right-hand side.
Distance between the first element of the columns of the right-hand side in the array .
Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Getri(System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary: Computes the inverse of a matrix using the LU decomposition computed by .

remarks.para: This method inverts U and then computes inv(A) by solving the system inv(A)*L = inv(U) for inv(A).

member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows and columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
On input, array that contains the elements of the LU decomposition computed by . On output, the elements of the inverse of the matrix.
Offset into of the first element of the LU decomposition.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length that holds the pivot indexes computed by .

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. If greater than zero, it contains the 1-based index of the first zero element on the diagonal of U; the matrix is singular and its inverse could not be computed.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Gecon(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,`0,`0@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a general real matrix, in either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm, using the LU decomposition computed by .

remarks.para: The estimate is computed by estimating the norm of the inverse of the matrix.

member.param: A value that specifies the norm.
An integer specifying the number of rows and columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
Array that contains the elements of the LU decomposition computed by .
Offset into of the first element of the LU decomposition.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
The norm of type of the matrix.
On output, an estimate for the reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix.
Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Geqrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
DGEQRF computes a QR decomposition of a real M-by-N matrix A: A = Q * R.
Arguments =========
M (input) INTEGER The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.
N (input) INTEGER The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the diagonal of the array contain the min(M,N)-by-N upper trapezoidal matrix R (R is upper triangular if m >= n); the elements below the diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of min(m,n) elementary reflectors (see Further Details).
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).
TAU (output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors (see Further Details).
WORK (workspace/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO = 0, WORK(1) returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N). For optimum performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
Further Details ===============
The matrix Q is represented as a product of elementary reflectors
Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k), where k = min(m,n).
Each H(i) has the form
H(i) = I - tau * v * v'
where tau is a real scalar, and v is a real vector with v(1:i-1) = 0 and v(i) = 1; v(i+1:m) is stored on exit inthis. A(i+1:m,i), and tau inthis. TAU(i).

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Ormqr(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixOperationSide,Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Multiplies the orthogonal component of a QR decomposition and a matrix.
member.param: A value that indicates whether the orthogonal matrix is the left or the right operand.
A value that indicates whether the orthogonal matrix should be transposed.
The number of rows of the matrix.
The number of columns of the matrix.
The number of columns that define the orthogonal matrix.
A array containing the components of the QR decomposition as computed by .
The offset of the first component of the QR decomposition in the array .
The distance between columns of the QR decomposition in the array .
A array containing the scalar factors of the QR decomposition as returned by .
The offset of the first factor in the array.
A array containing the components of the matrix to be multiplied.
The offset of the first component of the matrix in the array .
The distance between columns of the matrix .
On output, a zero value indicates success.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Lange(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes the norm of a matrix.
member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
Array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
A value that specifies the norm to compute.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Trtrs(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixTriangle,Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixDiagonal,System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)

summary.para: Solves a triangular system of the form A * X = B or A**T * X = B, where A is a triangular matrix of order N, and B is an N-by-NRHS matrix.

param.name: storageTriangle
trans
param.code: TRANS is CHARACTER*1 Specifies the form of the system of equations: = 'N': A * X = B (No transpose) = 'T': A**T * X = B (Transpose) = 'C': A**H * X = B (Conjugate transpose = Transpose)

param.name: diag
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: nrhs
param.code: NRHS is INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.

param.name: a
param.code: A is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The triangular matrix A. If UPLO = 'U', the leading N-by-N upper triangular part of the array A contains the upper triangular matrix, and the strictly lower triangular part of A is not referenced. If UPLO = 'L', the leading N-by-N lower triangular part of the array A contains the lower triangular matrix, and the strictly upper triangular part of A is not referenced. If DIAG = 'U', the diagonal elements of A are also not referenced and are assumed to be 1.

member.param: Offset into of the first element of the matrix.

param.name: lda
param.code: LDA is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: b
param.code: B is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, if INFO = 0, the solution matrix X.

member.param: Offset into of the first element of the matrix.

param.name: ldb
param.code: LDB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, the i-th diagonal element of A is zero, indicating that the matrix is singular and the solutions X have not been computed.

para.code: A check is made to verify that A is nonsingular.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Trtri(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixTriangle,Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixDiagonal,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)

summary.para: Computes the inverse of a real upper or lower triangular matrix A.

param.name: storageTriangle
diag
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.code: A is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the triangular matrix A. If UPLO = 'U', the leading N-by-N upper triangular part of the array A contains the upper triangular matrix, and the strictly lower triangular part of A is not referenced. If UPLO = 'L', the leading N-by-N lower triangular part of the array A contains the lower triangular matrix, and the strictly upper triangular part of A is not referenced. If DIAG = 'U', the diagonal elements of A are also not referenced and are assumed to be 1. On exit, the (triangular) inverse of the original matrix, in the same storage format.

member.param: Offset into of the first element of the matrix.

param.name: lda
param.code: LDA is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, A(i,i) is exactly zero. The triangular matrix is singular and its inverse can not be computed.

para.code: This is the Level 3 BLAS version of the algorithm.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Trcon(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixTriangle,Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixDiagonal,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,`0@,System.Int32@)

summary.para: Estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a triangular matrix A, in either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm.

param.name: norm
param.code: NORM is CHARACTER*1 Specifies whether the 1-norm condition number or the infinity-norm condition number is required: = '1' or 'O': 1-norm; = 'I': Infinity-norm.

param.name: storageTriangle
diag
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.code: A is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The triangular matrix A. If UPLO = 'U', the leading N-by-N upper triangular part of the array A contains the upper triangular matrix, and the strictly lower triangular part of A is not referenced. If UPLO = 'L', the leading N-by-N lower triangular part of the array A contains the lower triangular matrix, and the strictly upper triangular part of A is not referenced. If DIAG = 'U', the diagonal elements of A are also not referenced and are assumed to be 1.

member.param: Offset into of the first element of the matrix.

param.name: lda
param.code: LDA is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: rcond
param.code: RCOND is DOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(norm(A) * norm(inv(A))).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

para.code: The norm of A is computed and an estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), then the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / ( norm(A) * norm(inv(A)) ).

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.Generic.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ILapack`1.Lantr(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixTriangle,Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixDiagonal,System.Int32,System.Int32,`0[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes the norm of a triangular matrix.
member.param: A value that specifies whether the matrix is an upper or lower triangular matrix.
A value thst specifies whether or not is unit triangular.
An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
Array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
A value that specifies the norm to compute.

summary.para: Computes the Cholesky factorization of a real symmetric positive definite matrix A.

param.name: uplo
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.code: A is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the symmetric matrix A. If UPLO = 'U', the leading N-by-N upper triangular part of A contains the upper triangular part of the matrix A, and the strictly lower triangular part of A is not referenced. If UPLO = 'L', the leading N-by-N lower triangular part of A contains the lower triangular part of the matrix A, and the strictly upper triangular part of A is not referenced. On exit, if INFO = 0, the factor U or L from the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T.
LDA is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, the leading minor of order i is not positive definite, and the factorization could not be completed.

para.code: The factorization has the form A = U**T * U, if UPLO = 'U', or A = L * L**T, if UPLO = 'L', where U is an upper triangular matrix and L is lower triangular. This is the block version of the algorithm, calling Level 3 BLAS.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: November 2011

summary.para: Computes the inverse of a real symmetric positive definite matrix A using the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T computed by DPOTRF.

param.name: uplo
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.code: A is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the triangular factor U or L from the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T, as computed by DPOTRF. On exit, the upper or lower triangle of the (symmetric) inverse of A, overwriting the input factor U or L.
LDA is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, the (i,i) element of the factor U or L is zero, and the inverse could not be computed.

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: November 2011

summary.para: Solves a system of linear equations A*X = B with a symmetric positive definite matrix A using the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T computed by DPOTRF.

param.name: uplo
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: nrhs
param.code: NRHS is INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.

param.name: a
param.code: A is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The triangular factor U or L from the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T, as computed by DPOTRF.
LDA is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: b
param.code: B is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, the solution matrix X.
LDB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: November 2011

summary.para: Estimates the reciprocal of the condition number (in the 1-norm) of a real symmetric positive definite matrix using the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T computed by DPOTRF.

param.name: uplo
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: a
param.code: A is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The triangular factor U or L from the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T, as computed by DPOTRF.
LDA is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,N).

param.name: anorm
param.code: ANORM is DOUBLE PRECISION The 1-norm (or infinity-norm) of the symmetric matrix A.

param.name: rcond
param.code: RCOND is DOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(ANORM * AINVNM), where AINVNM is an estimate of the 1-norm of inv(A) computed in this routine.

param.name: work
param.code: WORK is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (3*N)

param.name: iwork
param.code: IWORK is INTEGER array, dimension (N)

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

para.code: An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / (ANORM * norm(inv(A))).

remarks.para: Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: November 2011

summary.para: Computes an LU factorization of a real m-by-n band matrix A using partial pivoting with row interchanges.

param.name: m
param.code: M is INTEGER The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.

param.name: n
param.code: N is INTEGER The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: kl
param.code: KL is INTEGER The number of subdiagonals within the band of A. KL >= 0.

param.name: ku
param.code: KU is INTEGER The number of superdiagonals within the band of A. KU >= 0.

param.name: ab
param.code: AB is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDAB,N) On entry, the matrix A in band storage, in rows KL+1 to 2*KL+KU+1; rows 1 to KL of the array need not be set. The j-th column of A is stored in the j-th column of the array AB as follows: AB(kl+ku+1+i-j,j) = A(i,j) for max(1,j-ku)<=i<=min(m,j+kl) On exit, details of the factorization: U is stored as an upper triangular band matrix with KL+KU superdiagonals in rows 1 to KL+KU+1, and the multipliers used during the factorization are stored in rows KL+KU+2 to 2*KL+KU+1. See below for further details.

param.name: ldab
param.code: LDAB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array AB. LDAB >= 2*KL+KU+1.

param.name: ipiv
param.code: IPIV is INTEGER array, dimension (min(M,N)) The pivot indices; for 1 <= i <= min(M,N), row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIV(i).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = +i, U(i,i) is exactly zero. The factorization has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

para.code: This is the blocked version of the algorithm, calling Level 3 BLAS.

The band storage scheme is illustrated by the following example, when M = N = 6, KL = 2, KU = 1: On entry: On exit: * * * + + + * * * u14 u25 u36 * * + + + + * * u13 u24 u35 u46 * a12 a23 a34 a45 a56 * u12 u23 u34 u45 u56 a11 a22 a33 a44 a55 a66 u11 u22 u33 u44 u55 u66 a21 a32 a43 a54 a65 * m21 m32 m43 m54 m65 * a31 a42 a53 a64 * * m31 m42 m53 m64 * * Array elements marked * are not used by the routine; elements marked + need not be set on entry, but are required by the routine to store elements of U because of fill-in resulting from the row interchanges.

summary.para: Solves a system of linear equations A * X = B or A**T * X = B with a general band matrix A using the LU factorization computed by DGBTRF.

param.name: trans
param.code: TRANS is CHARACTER*1 Specifies the form of the system of equations. = 'N': A * X = B (No transpose) = 'T': A**T* X = B (Transpose) = 'C': A**T* X = B (Conjugate transpose = Transpose)

param.name: n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: kl
param.code: KL is INTEGER The number of subdiagonals within the band of A. KL >= 0.

param.name: ku
param.code: KU is INTEGER The number of superdiagonals within the band of A. KU >= 0.

param.name: nrhs
param.code: NRHS is INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.

param.name: ab
param.code: AB is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDAB,N) Details of the LU factorization of the band matrix A, as computed by DGBTRF. U is stored as an upper triangular band matrix with KL+KU superdiagonals in rows 1 to KL+KU+1, and the multipliers used during the factorization are stored in rows KL+KU+2 to 2*KL+KU+1.
LDAB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array AB. LDAB >= 2*KL+KU+1.

param.name: ipiv
param.code: IPIV is INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indices; for 1 <= i <= N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIV(i).

param.name: b
param.code: B is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, the solution matrix X.

param.name: ldb
param.code: LDB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

summary.para: Estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a real general band matrix A, in either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm, using the LU factorization computed by DGBTRF.

param.name: norm
param.code: NORM is CHARACTER*1 Specifies whether the 1-norm condition number or the infinity-norm condition number is required: = '1' or 'O': 1-norm; = 'I': Infinity-norm.

param.name: n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: kl
param.code: KL is INTEGER The number of subdiagonals within the band of A. KL >= 0.

param.name: ku
param.code: KU is INTEGER The number of superdiagonals within the band of A. KU >= 0.

param.name: ab
param.code: AB is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDAB,N) Details of the LU factorization of the band matrix A, as computed by DGBTRF. U is stored as an upper triangular band matrix with KL+KU superdiagonals in rows 1 to KL+KU+1, and the multipliers used during the factorization are stored in rows KL+KU+2 to 2*KL+KU+1.

param.name: ldab
param.code: LDAB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array AB. LDAB >= 2*KL+KU+1.

param.name: ipiv
param.code: IPIV is INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indices; for 1 <= i <= N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIV(i).

param.name: aNorm
param.code: ANORM is DOUBLE PRECISION If NORM = '1' or 'O', the 1-norm of the original matrix A. If NORM = 'I', the infinity-norm of the original matrix A.

param.name: rcond
param.code: RCOND is DOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(norm(A) * norm(inv(A))).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

para.code: An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / ( norm(A) * norm(inv(A)) ).

summary.para: Solves a triangular system of the form A * X = B or A**T * X = B, where A is a triangular band matrix of order N, and B is an N-by NRHS matrix.

param.name: storageTriangle
trans
param.code: TRANS is CHARACTER*1 Specifies the form the system of equations: = 'N': A * X = B (No transpose) = 'T': A**T * X = B (Transpose) = 'C': A**H * X = B (Conjugate transpose = Transpose)

param.name: diag
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: kd
param.code: KD is INTEGER The number of superdiagonals or subdiagonals of the triangular band matrix A. KD >= 0.

param.name: nrhs
param.code: NRHS is INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.

param.name: ab
param.code: AB is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDAB,N) The upper or lower triangular band matrix A, stored in the first kd+1 rows of AB. The j-th column of A is stored in the j-th column of the array AB as follows: if UPLO = 'U', AB(kd+1+i-j,j) = A(i,j) for max(1,j-kd)<=i<=j; if UPLO = 'L', AB(1+i-j,j) = A(i,j) for j<=i<=min(n,j+kd). If DIAG = 'U', the diagonal elements of A are not referenced and are assumed to be 1.

param.name: ldab
param.code: LDAB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array AB. LDAB >= KD+1.

param.name: b
param.code: B is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, if INFO = 0, the solution matrix X.

param.name: ldb
param.code: LDB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, the i-th diagonal element of A is zero, indicating that the matrix is singular and the solutions X have not been computed.

para.code: A check is made to verify that A is nonsingular.

summary.para: Computes the Cholesky factorization of a real symmetric positive definite band matrix A.

param.name: storageTriangle
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: kd
param.code: KD is INTEGER The number of superdiagonals of the matrix A if UPLO = 'U', or the number of subdiagonals if UPLO = 'L'. KD >= 0.

param.name: ab
param.code: AB is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDAB,N) On entry, the upper or lower triangle of the symmetric band matrix A, stored in the first KD+1 rows of the array. The j-th column of A is stored in the j-th column of the array AB as follows: if UPLO = 'U', AB(kd+1+i-j,j) = A(i,j) for max(1,j-kd)<=i<=j; if UPLO = 'L', AB(1+i-j,j) = A(i,j) for j<=i<=min(n,j+kd). On exit, if INFO = 0, the triangular factor U or L from the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T of the band matrix A, in the same storage format as A.

param.name: ldab
param.code: LDAB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array AB. LDAB >= KD+1.

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, the leading minor of order i is not positive definite, and the factorization could not be completed.

para.code: The factorization has the form A = U**T * U, if UPLO = 'U', or A = L * L**T, if UPLO = 'L', where U is an upper triangular matrix and L is lower triangular.

The band storage scheme is illustrated by the following example, when N = 6, KD = 2, and UPLO = 'U': On entry: On exit: * * a13 a24 a35 a46 * * u13 u24 u35 u46 * a12 a23 a34 a45 a56 * u12 u23 u34 u45 u56 a11 a22 a33 a44 a55 a66 u11 u22 u33 u44 u55 u66 Similarly, if UPLO = 'L' the format of A is as follows: On entry: On exit: a11 a22 a33 a44 a55 a66 l11 l22 l33 l44 l55 l66 a21 a32 a43 a54 a65 * l21 l32 l43 l54 l65 * a31 a42 a53 a64 * * l31 l42 l53 l64 * * Array elements marked * are not used by the routine.

remarks.para: Peter Mayes and Giuseppe Radicati, IBM ECSEC, Rome, March 23, 1989
Authors: Univ. of Tennessee, Univ. of California Berkeley, Univ. of Colorado Denver, NAG Ltd.
Date: November 2011

summary.para: Solves a system of linear equations A*X = B with a symmetric positive definite band matrix A using the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T computed by DPBTRF.

param.name: storageTriangle
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: kd
param.code: KD is INTEGER The number of superdiagonals of the matrix A if UPLO = 'U', or the number of subdiagonals if UPLO = 'L'. KD >= 0.

param.name: nrhs
param.code: NRHS is INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.

param.name: ab
param.code: AB is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDAB,N) The triangular factor U or L from the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T of the band matrix A, stored in the first KD+1 rows of the array. The j-th column of U or L is stored in the j-th column of the array AB as follows: if UPLO ='U', AB(kd+1+i-j,j) = U(i,j) for max(1,j-kd)<=i<=j; if UPLO ='L', AB(1+i-j,j) = L(i,j) for j<=i<=min(n,j+kd).

param.name: ldab
param.code: LDAB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array AB. LDAB >= KD+1.

param.name: b
param.code: B is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, the solution matrix X.

param.name: ldb
param.code: LDB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= max(1,N).

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

summary.para: Estimates the reciprocal of the condition number (in the 1-norm) of a real symmetric positive definite band matrix using the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T computed by DPBTRF.

param.name: storageTriangle
n
param.code: N is INTEGER The order of the matrix A. N >= 0.

param.name: kd
param.code: KD is INTEGER The number of superdiagonals of the matrix A if UPLO = 'U', or the number of subdiagonals if UPLO = 'L'. KD >= 0.

param.name: ab
param.code: AB is DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDAB,N) The triangular factor U or L from the Cholesky factorization A = U**T*U or A = L*L**T of the band matrix A, stored in the first KD+1 rows of the array. The j-th column of U or L is stored in the j-th column of the array AB as follows: if UPLO ='U', AB(kd+1+i-j,j) = U(i,j) for max(1,j-kd)<=i<=j; if UPLO ='L', AB(1+i-j,j) = L(i,j) for j<=i<=min(n,j+kd).

param.name: ldab
param.code: LDAB is INTEGER The leading dimension of the array AB. LDAB >= KD+1.

param.name: aNorm
param.code: ANORM is DOUBLE PRECISION The 1-norm (or infinity-norm) of the symmetric band matrix A.

param.name: rcond
param.code: RCOND is DOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(ANORM * AINVNM), where AINVNM is an estimate of the 1-norm of inv(A) computed in this routine.

param.name: info
param.code: INFO is INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

para.code: An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / (ANORM * norm(inv(A))).

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ComplexLapack
member.summary: Specifies the methods that must be implemented by a class to support DoubleComplex-precision real LAPACK routines for general matrices.

remarks.para: The Linear Algebra PACKage (LAPACK) is the de facto standard for more complex linear algebra problems. It complements the Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines (BLAS), which defines standards for low level vector and matrix operations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ComplexLapack.Zgetrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
ZGETRF computes an LU decomposition of a general M-by-N matrix A using partial pivoting with row interchanges.
The decomposition has the form
A = P * L * U
where P is a permutation matrix, L is lower triangular with unit diagonal elements (lower trapezoidal if m > n), and U is upper triangular (upper trapezoidal if m < n).
This is the right-looking Level 3 BLAS version of the algorithm.
member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
DoubleComplex precision array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length min(,) that will hold the pivot indexes. Row i of the matrix was interchanged with row [i].

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ComplexLapack.Zgetrs(Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,System.Int32,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
ZGETRS solves a system of linear equations A * X = B or A' * X = B with a general N-by-N matrix A using the LU decomposition computed by ZGETRF.
Arguments =========
TRANS (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies the form of the system of equations: = 'N': A * X = B (No transpose) = TransposeOperation.Transpose: A'* X = B (Transpose) = 'C': A'* X = B (Conjugate transpose = Transpose)
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
NRHS (input) INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.
A (input) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by ZGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
IPIV (input) INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indexes from ZGETRF; for 1< =i< =N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIVi.
B (input/output) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, the solution matrix X.
LDB (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= Max(1,N).
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
=====================================================================

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ComplexLapack.Zgetri(System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
ZGETRI computes the inverse of a matrix using the LU decomposition computed by ZGETRF.
This method inverts U and then computes inv(A) by solving the system inv(A)*L = inv(U) for inv(A).
Arguments =========
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by ZGETRF. On exit, if INFO = 0, the inverse of the original matrix A.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
IPIV (input) INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indexes from ZGETRF; for 1< =i< =N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIVi.
WORK (workspace/output) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO =0, then WORK(1) returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= Max(1,N). For optimal performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize returned by ILAENV.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, U(i,i) is exactly zero; the matrix is singular and its inverse could not be computed.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ComplexLapack.Zgecon(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double@,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
ZGECON estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a general real matrix A, inthis. either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm, using the LU decomposition computed by ZGETRF.
An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / ( norm(A) * norm(inv(A)) ).
Arguments =========
NORM (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies whether the 1-norm condition number or the infinity-norm condition number is required: = '1' or 'O': 1-norm; = 'I': Infinity-norm.
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by ZGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
ANORM (input) ZOUBLE PRECISION If NORM = '1' or 'O', the 1-norm of the original matrix A. If NORM = 'I', the infinity-norm of the original matrix A.
RCOND (output) ZOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(norm(A) * norm(inv(A))).
WORK (workspace) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (4*N)
IWORK (workspace) INTEGER array, dimension (N)
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ComplexLapack.Zgeqrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
ZGEQRF computes a QR decomposition of a real M-by-N matrix A: A = Q * R.
Arguments =========
M (input) INTEGER The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.
N (input) INTEGER The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the diagonal of the array contain the min(M,N)-by-N upper trapezoidal matrix R (R is upper triangular if m >= n); the elements below the diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of min(m,n) elementary reflectors (see Further Zetails).
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).
TAU (output) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors (see Further Zetails).
WORK (workspace/output) ZOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO = 0, WORK(1) returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N). For optimum performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
Further Zetails ===============
The matrix Q is represented as a product of elementary reflectors
Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k), where k = min(m,n).
Each H(i) has the form
H(i) = I - tau * v * v'
where tau is a real scalar, and v is a real vector with v(1:i-1) = 0 and v(i) = 1; v(i+1:m) is stored on exit inthis. A(i+1:m,i), and tau inthis. TAU(i).
Solves a complex triangular system of equations.
member.param: A value that indicates whether the matrix is upper or lower triangular.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexBandVector
member.summary: Represents a that has one or more zero components at the beginning and/or at the end.
member.remarks:
Use the ComplexBandVector class to represent a vector with zero components at the beginning or at the end. The name derives from the fact that the rows and columns of a band matrix have this form.
Many of the standard methods for vectors have been optimized to take advantage of this special structure.
The and specify the index of the first and last non-zero element. These values must be specified in the constructor. Components with an index less than or greater than cannot be modified. Any attempt to do so will result in a . You can verify if a component can be modified by calling the method.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexVector
member.summary: Represents a vector, a one-dimensional array of real numbers.
member.remarks:
The class represents a one-dimensional array of single-precision complex floating-point numbers.
The ComplexVector class provides methods and properties for all the common operations on vectors, including norms, dot products, as well as retrieving extreme values from a vector.
Overloaded versions of the major arithmetic operators are provided for languages that support them. For languages that don't support operator overloading, equivalent methods are supplied.
To allow for greater efficiency, overloaded instance methods are available for many compound operations on vectors.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexVector.CloneData
member.summary: If possible, gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a column in the matrix. Changing an element in the vector changes the corresponding element in the matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexVector.InverseFourierTransform(Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexDenseVector)
member.summary: Returns the inverse Fourier transform of a vector.
member.param: A .
member.returns: A containing the inverse Fourier transform of .
member.exception: is
member.remarks:
This method returns the real part of the inverse transform. If the length of is odd, then only the first half of is used in the calculation.
The Fourier transform of a real vector has a certain symmetry: it is equal to the conjugate of the same vector with its elements in reverse order. If does not have this symmetry, then the inverse transform has a nonzero imaginary part, and this method will return a wrong or incomplete result. Use the to obtain the full, complex inverse Fourier transform of a complex vector.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexBandVector.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a column in the matrix. Changing an element in the vector changes the corresponding element in the matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this instance will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexCholeskyDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the Cholesky decomposition of a positive-definite .
member.remarks:
The Cholesky decomposition of a real hermitian positive definite matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= LLH, where L is a lower-triangular matrix or in the form A= UHU, where U is a upper-triangular matrix.. Which form depends on whether the elements of the Hermitian matrix are stored in the lower or upper triangular part.
ComplexCholeskyDecomposition can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten with the result of the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
ComplexCholeskyDecomposition inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations where the matrix of the system is hermitian and positive definite. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant the inverse, and an estimate for the condition number.
To solve a general (non-hermitian or non-positive definite)system of equations, use the class instead.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexDecomposition
member.summary: Represents a matrix decomposition.
member.remarks:
The ComplexDecomposition class represents a decomposition of a matrix into a product of matrices with specific properties.
The ComplexDecomposition class defines methods and properties that are shared by all decomposition classes. This includes methods related to solving systems of simultaneous linear equations defined by the abstract base class.
The ComplexDecomposition class is an abstract base class and cannot be instantiated directly. Instead, use one of its derived classes. These are:
Class Description
Represents a decomposition into a lower and an upper-triangular matrix.
Represents a decomposition into an orthogonal and an upper triangular matrix.
Represents the decomposition of a into the product of a lower-triangular matrix and its conjugate transpose.
Notes to inheritors: When you inherit from , you must override the following members: , , , , , .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexLinearTransformation
member.summary: Defines methods for the solution of a system of simultaneous linear equations and related operations.
member.remarks:
LinearTransformation is implemented by all classes and all classes that represent matrix decompositions.
The solution of a system of simultaneous linear equations represented by a is one of the most common tasks in linear algebra. The mechanism, which is overloaded, defines a common method for all classes that can represent matrices. This not only includes the class and its descendants, but also the class and its descendants.
LinearTransformation also defines operations that are related to solving systems of equations, such as calculating the matrix , the and an estimate for the .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexLinearTransformation.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of a matrix.
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the matrix.
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.returns: true if the matrix is singular; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
A matrix is singular when its rows or columns are not linearly independent.
A singular matrix does not have an inverse, and a system of simultaneous linear equation corresponding to the matrix does not have a solution.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Performs the actual decomposition.
member.remarks:
Inheritors override this method to perform the actual decomposition. The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call Decompose explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until Decompose is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

member.summary: Gets the underlying matrix of the decomposition.
member.remarks:
Every decomposition is the decomposition of some matrix. This is the matrix that is returned by this property.
Note that if the property is true, then the components of the base matrix after the decomposition has been calculated are no longer valid.

member.remarks:
Once the decomposition is completed, this value becomes read-only. If you try to set it after the decomposition has been calculated, an is thrown.
This property is only meaningful when the base matrix of the decomposition is a . When the base matrix is of another matrix type, it is never overwritten.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexCholeskyDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the factorized .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices.
For a Cholesky factorized matrix A = GTG, the determinant is the square of the product of the diagonal elements of G.
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexCholeskyDecomposition.GetInverse
member.summary: Calculates the inverse of the factorized .
member.returns: A that is the inverse matrix of the base matrix of this decomposition.
member.remarks:
The inverse of a matrix is the matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, gives an identity matrix.
If the matrix is singular, its inverse does not exist and a is thrown.
This method uses the LAPACK routine DPOTRI.
member.exception: The matrix is singular.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexCholeskyDecomposition.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the decomposed .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .
This method uses the LAPACK routine DPOCON.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexCholeskyDecomposition.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a column in the matrix. Changing an element in the vector changes the corresponding element in the matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.
A object always has its own copy of the component data. Calling this method is not necessary.

member.summary: Represents a general, dense, square or rectangular .
member.remarks:
A matrix is a two-dimensional array of real numbers. Use the ComplexDenseMatrix class to represent general, dense matrices. It is the most general implementation of the class. No components are assumed to have a specific value, and no relationship is assumed to exist between different components.
The components of a ComplexDenseMatrix are stored in a one-dimensional array of values. By default, components that are adjacent in a column of the matrix are adjacent in the storage array. The components are said to be stored in column major order. It is also possible to have elements stored in row major order.
The ComplexDenseMatrix class implements algorithms using the general matrix BLAS and LAPACK routines. These routines assume matrix components are stored in column major order. However, any necessary conversions are performed transparantly. No additional work is needed. In some cases there might be a small performance penalty.
Because ComplexDenseMatrix can represent any matrix, it is often used as the return type of matrix operations.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexMatrix
member.summary: Represents a matrix, a two-dimensional array of real numbers.
member.remarks:
ComplexMatrix is the base class for representing real matrices, two-dimensional arrays of float-precision floating-point numbers. An application can perform operations on matrices using instances of the ComplexMatrix class, while descendant classes implement specialized algorithms for specific types of matrices.
The ComplexMatrix class provides methods and properties for all the common operations on matrices, including arithmetic operations, calculating norms and solving systems of simultaneous linear equations. Various methods allow you to access individual components as well as rows and columns and submatrices.
Since ComplexMatrix is an base class and cannot be instantiated directly. Instead, use one of its derived classes. These are:
Class Description
Represents a general, dense, square or rectangular matrix.
Represents an upper or lower-triangular matrix, a matrix whose elements below or above the main diagonal are zero.
Represents a square matrix whose elements are symmetrical around the main diagonal.
Note that the specialized classes exploit certain structural properties to perform many calculations more quickly than the general algorithms implemented by .
ComplexMatrix provides an indexer property. For convenient access to the rows or columns of a ComplexMatrix or parts thereof, use the and methods.
Overloaded versions of the major arithmetic operators are provided for languages that support them. For languages that don't support operator overloading, equivalent methods are supplied.
Many matrix decompositions exist, serving a variety of purposes. Each of them has its own class. In this release the LU decomposition and the QR decomposition are supported. For positive-definite hermitian matrices, the is available.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexMatrix.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the values. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.
This overload of the CloneData method stores elements in elementOrder.

member.remarks:
The transpose of a matrix is the matrix with rows and columns exchanged. The transpose of a matrix with m rows and n columns is a matrix with n rows and m columns.
The conjugate transpose is the conjugate of the transpose of a matrix. Each component is the conjugate of the corresponding component of the transpose of the original matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of this .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexMatrix.GetConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates the condition number of this .
member.returns: The condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Calculating the singular values is an expensive operation. The method is faster, but returns an approximation to the condition number.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexMatrix.IsSingular
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this matrix is singular.
member.returns: true if the matrix is singular; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
A matrix is singular when its rows or columns are not linearly independent.
A singular matrix does not have an inverse, and a system of simultaneous linear equation corresponding to the matrix does not have a unique solution.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexMatrix.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the QR decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexDenseMatrix.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.
This overload of the CloneData method stores elements in elementOrder.

member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory, in the elementOrder specified by the parameter.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexDenseMatrix.MultiplyByConjugateTranspose
member.summary: Multiplies this by its .
member.returns: A that is the product of this with its conjugate transpose.
member.remarks:
Some applications, for example the solution of a least squares problem using normal equations, require the product of a matrix with its own transpose. This method performs this operation.
The resulting matrix is always Hermitian. This is why a is returned, rather than a more general .
This method uses the BLAS routine ZHERK.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexDenseVector
member.summary: Represents a with arbitrary components.
member.remarks:
The ComplexDenseVector class represents a one-dimensional array of float-precision floating-point numbers.
The ComplexVector class provides methods and properties for all the common operations on vectors, including norms, dot products, as well as retrieving extreme values from a vector.
Overloaded versions of the major arithmetic operators are provided for languages that support them. For languages that don't support operator overloading, equivalent methods are supplied.
To allow for greater efficiency, overloaded instance methods are available for many compound operations on vectors.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexDenseVector.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a column in the matrix. Changing an element in the vector changes the corresponding element in the matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexHermitianMatrix
member.summary: Represents a that is symmetrical about the main diagonal.
member.remarks:
Use the ComplexHermitianMatrix class to represent dense matrices whose elements are symmetrical about the main diagonal. Symmetric matrices are always square.
The components of a ComplexHermitianMatrix are stored in a one-dimensional array of values. Thanks to the symmetry, only the upper or lower-triangular portion needs to be stored.
Symmetric matrices can be constructed from scratch, or they can be derived or extracted from the upper or lower triangular portion of a using one of the methods.
The ComplexHermitianMatrix class implements algorithms using the hermitian matrix BLAS and LAPACK routines. Symmetric matrices are always stored in column-major order.

member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory, in column-major order.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexHermitianMatrix.ConjugateTranspose
member.summary: Returns the conjugate transpose of this instance.
member.returns: A representing the conjugate transpose of this .
member.remarks:
The transpose of a matrix is the matrix with rows and columns exchanged. The transpose of a matrix with m rows and n columns is a matrix with n rows and m columns.
The conjugate transpose is the conjugate of the transpose of a matrix. Each component is the conjugate of the corresponding component of the transpose of the original matrix.
The conjugate transpose of a hermitian matrix is equal to the matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexHermitianMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleComplexLapack.Cgetrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
CGETRF computes an LU decomposition of a general M-by-N matrix A using partial pivoting with row interchanges.
The decomposition has the form
A = P * L * U
where P is a permutation matrix, L is lower triangular with unit diagonal elements (lower trapezoidal if m > n), and U is upper triangular (upper trapezoidal if m < n).
This is the right-looking Level 3 BLAS version of the algorithm.
member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
single-precision complex array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length min(,) that will hold the pivot indexes. Row i of the matrix was interchanged with row [i].

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Cero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleComplexLapack.Cgetrs(Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,System.Int32,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
CGETRS solves a system of linear equations A * X = B or A' * X = B with a general N-by-N matrix A using the LU decomposition computed by CGETRF.
Arguments =========
TRANS (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies the form of the system of equations: = 'N': A * X = B (No transpose) = TransposeOperation.Transpose: A'* X = B (Transpose) = 'C': A'* X = B (Conjugate transpose = Transpose)
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
NRHS (input) INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.
A (input) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by CGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
IPIV (input) INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indexes from CGETRF; for 1< =i< =N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIVi.
B (input/output) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, the solution matrix X.
LDB (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= Max(1,N).
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
=====================================================================

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleComplexLapack.Cgetri(System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
CGETRI computes the inverse of a matrix using the LU decomposition computed by CGETRF.
This method inverts U and then computes inv(A) by solving the system inv(A)*L = inv(U) for inv(A).
Arguments =========
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by CGETRF. On exit, if INFO = 0, the inverse of the original matrix A.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
IPIV (input) INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indexes from CGETRF; for 1< =i< =N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIVi.
WORK (workspace/output) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO =0, then WORK(1) returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= Max(1,N). For optimal performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize returned by ILAENV.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, U(i,i) is exactly zero; the matrix is singular and its inverse could not be computed.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleComplexLapack.Cgecon(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single@,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
CGECON estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a general real matrix A, inthis. either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm, using the LU decomposition computed by CGETRF.
An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / ( norm(A) * norm(inv(A)) ).
Arguments =========
NORM (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies whether the 1-norm condition number or the infinity-norm condition number is required: = '1' or 'O': 1-norm; = 'I': Infinity-norm.
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by CGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
ANORM (input) COUBLE PRECISION If NORM = '1' or 'O', the 1-norm of the original matrix A. If NORM = 'I', the infinity-norm of the original matrix A.
RCOND (output) COUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(norm(A) * norm(inv(A))).
WORK (workspace) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (4*N)
IWORK (workspace) INTEGER array, dimension (N)
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleComplexLapack.Cgeqrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32,Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex[],System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
CGEQRF computes a QR decomposition of a real M-by-N matrix A: A = Q * R.
Arguments =========
M (input) INTEGER The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.
N (input) INTEGER The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the diagonal of the array contain the min(M,N)-by-N upper trapezoidal matrix R (R is upper triangular if m >= n); the elements below the diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of min(m,n) elementary reflectors (see Further Cetails).
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).
TAU (output) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors (see Further Cetails).
WORK (workspace/output) COUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO = 0, WORK(1) returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N). For optimum performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
Further Cetails ===============
The matrix Q is represented as a product of elementary reflectors
Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k), where k = min(m,n).
Each H(i) has the form
H(i) = I - tau * v * v'
where tau is a real scalar, and v is a real vector with v(1:i-1) = 0 and v(i) = 1; v(i+1:m) is stored on exit inthis. A(i+1:m,i), and tau inthis. TAU(i).
Solves a complex triangular system of equations.
member.param: A value that indicates whether the matrix is upper or lower triangular.

A containing the outcomes of each of the observations in .
member.remarks:
Use this constructor to create a least squares solution based on the matrix of observations and the vector of outcomes. The number of rows in must equal the number of elements in . In addition, the number of rows in must be greater than or equal to the number of columns.
Each row in the matrix corresponds to an observation. The corresponding element of the vector specifies the outcome produced by this observation.
Because there are at least as many equations as there are unknowns, an exact solution is not possible. The goal is therefore to minimize the two-norm of the residual vector Ax - b, where A corresponds to and b corresponds to . The vector x with this property is the solution to this problem with minimal norm.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexLUDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the LU decomposition of a general .
member.remarks:
The LU decomposition of a matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= PLU, where P is a permutation matrix, L is a unit lower-triangular matrix, and U is an upper-triangular matrix.
ComplexLUDecomposition can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten by the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
ComplexLUDecomposition inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant, the inverse, and an estimate for the .

The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexLUDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Performs the actual LU decomposition.
member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call Decompose explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until Decompose is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.
