member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexLUDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the decomposed .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
For a LU factorized matrix PA = LU, the determinant is the product of the diagonal elements of U. Since L is defined to be unit triangular, so the product of its diagonal elements equals 1.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.

member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the matrix underlying this system of equations.
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexSingularValueDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the singular value decomposition of a complex matrix.
member.remarks:
The singular value decomposition (SVD) of a matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= USVH, where U and V are orthogonal matrices, and S is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal contains the singular values of the matrix.
can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten by the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant, the inverse, and an estimate for the .
In addition, the class provides some unique methods. The method calculates the pseudo-inverse of the matrix. This is a matrix A+ such that AA+A = A.
The managed implementation of the singular value decomposition is based on the LINPACK routine DSVDC. The native version uses the LAPACK routine ZGESDD.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexSingularValueDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Calculates the actual singular value decomposition.
member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexSingularValueDecomposition.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexSingularValueDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the decomposed .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
For a singular value decomposition A = USVH, the magnitude of the determinant is the product of the diagonal elements of S. Since U and V are orthogonal, their determinant is 1 or -1. This means that only the magnitude of the determinant is known, not its sign.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexSingularValueDecomposition.GetInverse
member.summary: Calculates the inverse of the factorized .
member.returns: A that is the matrix inverse of this instance.
member.remarks:
The inverse of a matrix is the matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, gives an identity matrix.
If the matrix is singular, its inverse does not exist and a is thrown.
The inverse is only defined for a square matrix. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.
The matrix is singular.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexSingularValueDecomposition.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.summary: Gets or sets which factors of the singular value decomposition should be calculated.
member.remarks:
Computing the singular value decomposition of a matrix is a relatively expensive operation. Not all applications require the full decomposition. By specifying which factors are required, significant time can be saved during the calculation.
The singular values are always computed. The calculation of the left and right singular vectors is optional.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexTriangularMatrix
member.summary: Represents a whose elements above or below the main diagonal are zero.
member.remarks:
Use the ComplexTriangularMatrix class to represent dense matrices whose elements above or below the diagonal are zero. The name is derived from the shape of the non-zero elements, which form a triangle. However, this class also represents rectangular matrices, whose non-zero elements may form a trapezoid.
A ComplexTriangularMatrix can be either upper or lower-triangular, depending on which components are non-zero. This property is available as the property. It is of type , and must be specified at construction.
Sometimes, the components on the diagonal are all equal to one. In this case, the matrix is said to be unit-diagonal, and the property will be true. Once again, this must be specified at the time the matrix is constructed.
Only the non-zero components of a triangular matrix can be modified. The diagonal components of a unit-diagonal matrix can't be modified. An attempt to do so will result in an . You can verify if a component can be modified by calling the method.
The components of a ComplexTriangularMatrix are stored in a one-dimensional array of values. By default, components that are adjacent in a column of the matrix are adjacent in the storage array. The components are said to be stored in column major order. It is also possible to have elements stored in row major order.
Triangular matrices can be constructed from scratch, or they can be derived or extracted from a using one of the or methods.
The rows and column vectors of a triangular matrix are of type .
The ComplexTriangularMatrix class implements algorithms using the triangular matrix BLAS and LAPACK routines. These routines assume matrix components are stored in column major order. However, any necessary conversions are performed transparantly. No additional work is needed. In some cases there might be a small performance penalty.
ComplexTriangularMatrix objects are used as properties of many matrix decompositions. Both factors of the LU decomposition are triangular. So is at least one factor of the Cholesky ComplexDecomposition and the QR ComplexDecomposition.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexTriangularMatrix.IsSingular
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the is singular.
member.returns: true if the matrix is singular; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
A matrix is singular when its rows or columns are not linearly independent. For a triangular matrix, this occurs when one of the elements on the diagonal is zero.
A singular matrix does not have an inverse, and a system of simultaneous linear equation corresponding to the matrix does not have a unique solution.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexTriangularMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of this .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.SingleComplexTriangularMatrix.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory, in column-major order.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.Lapack.Dgetrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
Computes an LU decomposition of a general M-by-N matrix A using partial pivoting with row interchanges.
The decomposition has the form
A = P * L * U
where P is a permutation matrix, L is lower triangular with unit diagonal elements (lower trapezoidal if m > n), and U is upper triangular (upper trapezoidal if m < n).
This is the right-looking Level 3 BLAS version of the algorithm.
member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length min(,) that will hold the pivot indexes. Row i of the matrix was interchanged with row [i].

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.Lapack.Dgetrs(Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Solves a system of linear equations with a general N-by-N matrix A using the LU decomposition computed by .
member.param: A value that specifies whether the regular or the transposed system should be solved.
An integer specifying the number of rows and columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns in the right-hand side matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
array specifying the -by- matrix containing the lower and upper triangular factors as computed by .
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array containing the pivot indexes computed by .
array specifying the -by- matrix containing the right-hand sides. On exit, this matrix is overwritten with the solution.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.Lapack.Dgetri(System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary: Computes the inverse of a matrix using the LU decomposition computed by .
member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows and columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
array specifying the -by- matrix containing the lower and upper triangular factors as computed by .
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array containing the pivot indexes computed by .
Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The matrix is singular and its inverse could not be computed.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.Lapack.Dgecon(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double@,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
DGECON estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a general real matrix A, inthis. either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm, using the LU decomposition computed by DGETRF.
An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / ( norm(A) * norm(inv(A)) ).
Arguments =========
NORM (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies whether the 1-norm condition number or the infinity-norm condition number is required: = '1' or 'O': 1-norm; = 'I': Infinity-norm.
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by DGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
ANORM (input) DOUBLE PRECISION If NORM = '1' or 'O', the 1-norm of the original matrix A. If NORM = 'I', the infinity-norm of the original matrix A.
RCOND (output) DOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(norm(A) * norm(inv(A))).
WORK (workspace) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (4*N)
IWORK (workspace) INTEGER array, dimension (N)
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.Lapack.Dgeqrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
DGEQRF computes a QR decomposition of a real M-by-N matrix A: A = Q * R.
Arguments =========
M (input) INTEGER The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.
N (input) INTEGER The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the diagonal of the array contain the min(M,N)-by-N upper trapezoidal matrix R (R is upper triangular if m >= n); the elements below the diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of min(m,n) elementary reflectors (see Further Details).
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).
TAU (output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors (see Further Details).
WORK (workspace/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO = 0, WORK(1) returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N). For optimum performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
Further Details ===============
The matrix Q is represented as a product of elementary reflectors
Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k), where k = min(m,n).
Each H(i) has the form
H(i) = I - tau * v * v'
where tau is a real scalar, and v is a real vector with v(1:i-1) = 0 and v(i) = 1; v(i+1:m) is stored on exit inthis. A(i+1:m,i), and tau inthis. TAU(i).

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.LinearAlgebraProvider
member.summary: Encapsulates the currently active BLAS implementation.

remarks.para: The classes in the namespace use the standard Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines (BLAS) whenever possible. The Extreme Optimization Mathematics Library for .NET provides two implementations. One is in 100% managed code. The other calls a native, highly optimized, processor-specific kernel.
This class exposes properties that allow you to specify the BLAS objects that are to be used by the classes in this namespace.

You can select the managed implementation by calling the method. To select the native implementation, call the method. The native kernel is used by default. This is the fastest option, especially for larger matrices, but also has a larger memory footprint.
Alternatively, you can plug in platform optimized versions by inheriting from the , , and abstract base classes.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ManagedLapack.Dgetrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary: DGETRF computes an LU decomposition of a general M-by-N matrix A using partial pivoting with row interchanges.

remarks.para: The decomposition has the form
where P is a permutation matrix, L is lower triangular with unit diagonal elements (lower trapezoidal if m > n), and U is upper triangular (upper trapezoidal if m < n).
This is the right-looking Level 3 BLAS version of the algorithm.

member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
double precision array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length Min(,) that will hold the pivot indexes. Row i of the matrix was interchanged with row [i].

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ManagedLapack.Dgetrs(Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
DGETRS solves a system of linear equations A * X = B or A' * X = B with a general N-by-N matrix A using the LU decomposition computed by DGETRF.
Arguments =========
TRANS (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies the form of the system of equations: = 'N': A * X = B (No transpose) = TransposeOperation.Transpose: A'* X = B (Transpose) = 'C': A'* X = B (Conjugate transpose = Transpose)
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
NRHS (input) INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.
A (input) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by DGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
IPIV (input) INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indexes from DGETRF; for 1< =i< =N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIVi.
B (input/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, the solution matrix X.
LDB (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= Max(1,N).
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
=====================================================================

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ManagedLapack.Dgetri(System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
DGETRI computes the inverse of a matrix using the LU decomposition computed by DGETRF.
This method inverts U and then computes inv(A) by solving the system inv(A)*L = inv(U) for inv(A).
Arguments =========
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by DGETRF. On exit, if INFO = 0, the inverse of the original matrix A.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
IPIV (input) INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indexes from DGETRF; for 1< =i< =N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIVi.
WORK (workspace/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO =0, then WORK1 returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= Max(1,N). For optimal performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize returned by ILAENV.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, U(i,i) is exactly zero; the matrix is singular and its inverse could not be computed.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ManagedLapack.Dgecon(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double@,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
DGECON estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a general real matrix A, inthis. either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm, using the LU decomposition computed by DGETRF.
An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / ( norm(A) * norm(inv(A)) ).
Arguments =========
NORM (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies whether the 1-norm condition number or the infinity-norm condition number is required: = '1' or 'O': 1-norm; = 'I': Infinity-norm.
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by DGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
ANORM (input) DOUBLE PRECISION If NORM = '1' or 'O', the 1-norm of the original matrix A. If NORM = 'I', the infinity-norm of the original matrix A.
RCOND (output) DOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(norm(A) * norm(inv(A))).
WORK (workspace) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (4*N)
IWORK (workspace) INTEGER array, dimension (N)
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ManagedLapack.Dgeqrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
DGEQRF computes a QR decomposition of a real M-by-N matrix A: A = Q * R.
Arguments =========
M (input) INTEGER The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.
N (input) INTEGER The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the diagonal of the array contain the Min(M,N)-by-N upper trapezoidal matrix R (R is upper triangular if m >= n); the elements below the diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of Min(m,n) elementary reflectors (see Further Details).
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,M).
TAU (output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (Min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors (see Further Details).
WORK (workspace/output) DOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO = 0, WORK1 returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= Max(1,N). For optimum performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
Further Details ===============
The matrix Q is represented as a product of elementary reflectors
Q = H1 H(2) . . . H(k), where k = Min(m,n).
Each H(i) has the form
H(i) = I - tau * vt * vt'
where tau is a real scalar, and vt is a real vector with vt(1:i-1) = 0 and vt(i) = 1; vt(i+1:m) is stored on exit inthis. A(i+1:m,i), and tau inthis. TAU(i).

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.ManagedLinearAlgebraProvider
member.summary: Encapsulates the currently active BLAS implementation.

remarks.para: The classes in the namespace use the standard Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines (BLAS) whenever possible. The Extreme Optimization Mathematics Library for .NET provides two implementations. One is in 100% managed code. The other calls a native, highly optimized, processor-specific kernel.
This class exposes properties that allow you to specify the BLAS objects that are to be used by the classes in this namespace.

You can select the managed implementation by calling the method. To select the native implementation, call the method. The native kernel is used by default. This is the fastest option, especially for larger matrices, but also has a larger memory footprint.
Alternatively, you can plug in platform optimized versions by inheriting from the , , and override base classes. You can then supply an instance of your class or classes as parameters to the method.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleLapack.Sgetrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
Computes an LU decomposition of a general M-by-N matrix A using partial pivoting with row interchanges.
The decomposition has the form
A = P * L * U
where P is a permutation matrix, L is lower triangular with unit diagonal elements (lower trapezoidal if m > n), and U is upper triangular (upper trapezoidal if m < n).
This is the right-looking Level 3 BLAS version of the algorithm.
member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length min(,) that will hold the pivot indexes. Row i of the matrix was interchanged with row [i].

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleLapack.Sgetrs(Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Solves a system of linear equations with a general N-by-N matrix A using the LU decomposition computed by .
member.param: A value that specifies whether the regular or the transposed system should be solved.
An integer specifying the number of rows and columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns in the right-hand side matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
array specifying the -by- matrix containing the lower and upper triangular factors as computed by .
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array containing the pivot indexes computed by .
array specifying the -by- matrix containing the right-hand sides. On exit, this matrix is overwritten with the solution.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleLapack.Sgecon(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single@,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
SGECON estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a general real matrix A, inthis. either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm, using the LU decomposition computed by SGETRF.
An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / ( norm(A) * norm(inv(A)) ).
Arguments =========
NORM (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies whether the 1-norm condition number or the infinity-norm condition number is required: = '1' or 'O': 1-norm; = 'I': Infinity-norm.
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by SGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
ANORM (input) SOUBLE PRECISION If NORM = '1' or 'O', the 1-norm of the original matrix A. If NORM = 'I', the infinity-norm of the original matrix A.
RCOND (output) SOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(norm(A) * norm(inv(A))).
WORK (workspace) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (4*N)
IWORK (workspace) INTEGER array, dimension (N)
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleLapack.Sgeqrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
SGEQRF computes a QR decomposition of a real M-by-N matrix A: A = Q * R.
Arguments =========
M (input) INTEGER The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.
N (input) INTEGER The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the diagonal of the array contain the min(M,N)-by-N upper trapezoidal matrix R (R is upper triangular if m >= n); the elements below the diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of min(m,n) elementary reflectors (see Further Setails).
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= max(1,M).
TAU (output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors (see Further Setails).
WORK (workspace/output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO = 0, WORK(1) returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= max(1,N). For optimum performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
Further Setails ===============
The matrix Q is represented as a product of elementary reflectors
Q = H(1) H(2) . . . H(k), where k = min(m,n).
Each H(i) has the form
H(i) = I - tau * v * v'
where tau is a real scalar, and v is a real vector with v(1:i-1) = 0 and v(i) = 1; v(i+1:m) is stored on exit inthis. A(i+1:m,i), and tau inthis. TAU(i).

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleLinearAlgebraProvider
member.summary: Encapsulates the currently active BLAS implementation.
member.remarks:
The classes in the namespace use the standard Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines (BLAS) whenever possible. The Extreme Optimization Mathematics Library for .NET provides two implementations. One is in 100% managed code. The other calls a native, highly optimized, processor-specific kernel.
This class exposes properties that allow you to specify the BLAS objects that are to be used by the classes in this namespace.
You can select the managed implementation by calling the method. To select the native implementation, call the method. The native kernel is used by default. This is the fastest option, especially for larger matrices, but also has a larger memory footprint.
Alternatively, you can plug in platform optimized versions by inheriting from the , , and abstract base classes. You can then supply an instance of your class or classes as parameters to the method.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleManagedLapack.Sgetrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary: SGETRF computes an LU decomposition of a general M-by-N matrix A using partial pivoting with row interchanges.

remarks.para: The decomposition has the form
where P is a permutation matrix, L is lower triangular with unit diagonal elements (lower trapezoidal if m > n), and U is upper triangular (upper trapezoidal if m < n).
This is the right-looking Level 3 BLAS version of the algorithm.

member.param: An integer specifying the number of rows of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
An integer specifying the number of columns of the matrix . Must be greater than or equal to zero.
float precision array specifying the -by- matrix to be factored. On exit, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U; the unit diagonal elements of L are not stored.
Offset into of the first element of the matrix.
The leading dimension of the array . Must be greater than or equal to Max(1,).
Integer array of length Min(,) that will hold the pivot indexes. Row i of the matrix was interchanged with row [i].

Reference to an integer containing a result code. Zero indicates success. Greater than zero indicates U(i,i) is exactly zero. The decomposition has been completed, but the factor U is exactly singular, and division by zero will occur if it is used to solve a system of equations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleManagedLapack.Sgetrs(Extreme.Mathematics.TransposeOperation,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
SGETRS solves a system of linear equations A * X = B or A' * X = B with a general N-by-N matrix A using the LU decomposition computed by SGETRF.
Arguments =========
TRANS (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies the form of the system of equations: = 'N': A * X = B (No transpose) = TransposeOperation.Transpose: A'* X = B (Transpose) = 'C': A'* X = B (Conjugate transpose = Transpose)
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
NRHS (input) INTEGER The number of right hand sides, i.e., the number of columns of the matrix B. NRHS >= 0.
A (input) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by SGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
IPIV (input) INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indexes from SGETRF; for 1< =i< =N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIVi.
B (input/output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDB,NRHS) On entry, the right hand side matrix B. On exit, the solution matrix X.
LDB (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array B. LDB >= Max(1,N).
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
=====================================================================

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleManagedLapack.Sgetri(System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32@)
member.summary:
SGETRI computes the inverse of a matrix using the LU decomposition computed by SGETRF.
This method inverts U and then computes inv(A) by solving the system inv(A)*L = inv(U) for inv(A).
Arguments =========
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by SGETRF. On exit, if INFO = 0, the inverse of the original matrix A.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
IPIV (input) INTEGER array, dimension (N) The pivot indexes from SGETRF; for 1< =i< =N, row i of the matrix was interchanged with row IPIVi.
WORK (workspace/output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO =0, then WORK1 returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= Max(1,N). For optimal performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize returned by ILAENV.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value > 0: if INFO = i, U(i,i) is exactly zero; the matrix is singular and its inverse could not be computed.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleManagedLapack.Sgecon(Extreme.Mathematics.MatrixNorm,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single@,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
SGECON estimates the reciprocal of the condition number of a general real matrix A, inthis. either the 1-norm or the infinity-norm, using the LU decomposition computed by SGETRF.
An estimate is obtained for norm(inv(A)), and the reciprocal of the condition number is computed as RCOND = 1 / ( norm(A) * norm(inv(A)) ).
Arguments =========
NORM (input) CHARACTER*1 Specifies whether the 1-norm condition number or the infinity-norm condition number is required: = '1' or 'O': 1-norm; = 'I': Infinity-norm.
N (input) INTEGER The elementOrder of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) The factors L and U from the decomposition A = P*L*U as computed by SGETRF.
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,N).
ANORM (input) SOUBLE PRECISION If NORM = '1' or 'O', the 1-norm of the original matrix A. If NORM = 'I', the infinity-norm of the original matrix A.
RCOND (output) SOUBLE PRECISION The reciprocal of the condition number of the matrix A, computed as RCOND = 1/(norm(A) * norm(inv(A))).
WORK (workspace) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (4*N)
IWORK (workspace) INTEGER array, dimension (N)
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleManagedLapack.Sgeqrf(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single[],System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
SGEQRF computes a QR decomposition of a real M-by-N matrix A: A = Q * R.
Arguments =========
M (input) INTEGER The number of rows of the matrix A. M >= 0.
N (input) INTEGER The number of columns of the matrix A. N >= 0.
A (input/output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LDA,N) On entry, the M-by-N matrix A. On exit, the elements on and above the diagonal of the array contain the Min(M,N)-by-N upper trapezoidal matrix R (R is upper triangular if m >= n); the elements below the diagonal, with the array TAU, represent the orthogonal matrix Q as a product of Min(m,n) elementary reflectors (see Further Setails).
LDA (input) INTEGER The leading dimension of the array A. LDA >= Max(1,M).
TAU (output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (Min(M,N)) The scalar factors of the elementary reflectors (see Further Setails).
WORK (workspace/output) SOUBLE PRECISION array, dimension (LWORK) On exit, if INFO = 0, WORK1 returns the optimal LWORK.
LWORK (input) INTEGER The dimension of the array WORK. LWORK >= Max(1,N). For optimum performance LWORK >= N*NB, where NB is the optimal blocksize.
If LWORK = -1, then a workspace query is assumed; the routine only calculates the optimal size of the WORK array, returns this value as the first entry of the WORK array, and no error message related to LWORK is issued by XERBLA.
INFO (output) INTEGER = 0: successful exit < 0: if INFO = -i, the i-th argument had an illegal value
Further Setails ===============
The matrix Q is represented as a product of elementary reflectors
Q = H1 H(2) . . . H(k), where k = Min(m,n).
Each H(i) has the form
H(i) = I - tau * vt * vt'
where tau is a real scalar, and vt is a real vector with vt(1:i-1) = 0 and vt(i) = 1; vt(i+1:m) is stored on exit inthis. A(i+1:m,i), and tau inthis. TAU(i).

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Providers.SingleManagedLinearAlgebraProvider
member.summary: Encapsulates the currently active BLAS implementation.
member.remarks:
The classes in the namespace use the standard Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines (BLAS) whenever possible. The Extreme Optimization Mathematics Library for .NET provides two implementations. One is in 100% managed code. The other calls a native, highly optimized, processor-specific kernel.
This class exposes properties that allow you to specify the BLAS objects that are to be used by the classes in this namespace.
You can select the managed implementation by calling the method. To select the native implementation, call the method. The native kernel is used by default. This is the fastest option, especially for larger matrices, but also has a larger memory footprint.
Alternatively, you can plug in platform optimized versions by inheriting from the , , and override base classes. You can then supply an instance of your class or classes as parameters to the method.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandCholeskyDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the Cholesky decomposition of a positive-definite symmetric .
member.remarks:
The Cholesky decomposition of a real symmetric positive definite matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= LLT, where L is a lower-triangular matrix.
can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten with the result of the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations where the matrix of the system is symmetric and positive definite. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant the inverse, and an estimate for the condition number.
To solve a general (non-symmetric or non-positive definite)system of equations, use the class instead.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDecomposition
member.summary: Represents a matrix decomposition.
member.remarks:
The class represents a decomposition of a matrix into a product of matrices with specific properties.
The class defines methods and properties that are shared by all decomposition classes. This includes methods related to solving systems of simultaneous linear equations defined by the abstract base class.
The class is an abstract base class and cannot be instantiated directly. Instead, use one of its derived classes. These are:
Class Description
Represents a decomposition into a lower and an upper-triangular matrix.
Represents a decomposition into an orthogonal and an upper triangular matrix.
Represents the decomposition of a into the product of a lower-triangular matrix and its transpose.
Notes to inheritors: When you inherit from , you must override the following members: , , , , , .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLinearTransformation
member.summary: Defines methods for the solution of a system of simultaneous linear equations and related operations.
member.remarks:
is implemented by all classes and all classes that represent matrix decompositions.
The solution of a system of simultaneous linear equations represented by a is one of the most common tasks in linear algebra. The mechanism, which is overloaded, defines a common method for all classes that can represent matrices. This not only includes the class and its descendants, but also the class and its descendants.
also defines operations that are related to solving systems of equations, such as calculating the matrix , the and an estimate for the .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLinearTransformation.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of a matrix.
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the matrix.
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLinearTransformation.IsSingular
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the is singular.
member.returns: true if the matrix is singular; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
A matrix is singular when its rows or columns are not linearly independent.
A singular matrix does not have an inverse, and a system of simultaneous linear equation corresponding to the matrix does not have a solution.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLinearTransformation.Rank
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: This method uses the default tolerance to determine rank.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLinearTransformation.Rank(System.Single)
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: The method that is used to determine the rank, as well as the exact meaning of the tolerance, depend on the implementation. The tolerance is always relative to some norm of the matrix.

The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Performs the actual decomposition.
member.remarks:
Inheritors override this method to perform the actual decomposition. The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDecomposition.IsSingular
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the of this decomposition is singular.
member.returns: true if the matrix is singular; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
A is singular when its rows or columns are not linearly independent.
A singular matrix does not have an inverse, and a system of simultaneous linear equation corresponding to the matrix does not have a unique solution.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDecomposition.BaseMatrix
member.summary: Gets the underlying matrix of the decomposition.
member.remarks:
Every decomposition is the decomposition of some matrix. This is the matrix that is returned by this property.
Note that if the property is true, then the components of the base matrix after the decomposition has been calculated are no longer valid.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDecomposition.Overwrite

member.remarks:
Once the decomposition is completed, this value becomes read-only. If you try to set it after the decomposition has been calculated, an is thrown.
This property is only meaningful when the base matrix of the decomposition is a . When the base matrix is of another matrix type, it is never overwritten.
member.exception: The property is read-only because the matrix has already been factorized.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandCholeskyDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the factorized .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices.
For a Cholesky factorized matrix A = GTG, the determinant is the square of the product of the diagonal elements of G.
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandCholeskyDecomposition.GetInverse
member.summary: Calculates the inverse of the factorized .
member.returns: A that is the matrix inverse of this instance.
member.remarks:
The inverse of a matrix is the matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, gives an identity matrix.
If the matrix is singular, its inverse does not exist and a is thrown.
This method uses the LAPACK routine DPOTRI.
member.exception: The matrix is singular.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandCholeskyDecomposition.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the decomposed .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .
This method uses the LAPACK routine DPOCON.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandCholeskyDecomposition.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandLUDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the LU decomposition of a .
member.remarks:
The LU decomposition of a matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= PLU, where P is a permutation matrix, L is a unit lower-triangular matrix, and U is an upper-triangular matrix.
You have a choice whether to preserve the matrix, or allow the to overwrite it. Because the LU decomposition with partial pivoting of a can increase the upper bandwidth, enough space must have been allocated when the was constructed.
Note that, if the matrix should be overwritten, sufficient space must have been allocated to store the upper triangular part.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant, the inverse, and an estimate for the .

For a LU factorized matrix PA = LU, the determinant is the product of the diagonal elements of U. Since L is defined to be unit triangular, so the product of its diagonal elements equals 1.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleMatrix
member.summary: Represents a matrix, a two-dimensional array of real numbers.
member.remarks:
is the base class for representing real matrices, two-dimensional arrays of float-precision floating-point numbers. An application can perform operations on matrices using instances of the class, while descendant classes implement specialized algorithms for specific types of matrices.
The class provides methods and properties for all the common operations on matrices, including arithmetic operations, calculating norms and solving systems of simultaneous linear equations. Various methods allow you to access individual components as well as rows and columns and submatrices.
Since is an base class and cannot be instantiated directly. Instead, use one of its derived classes. These are:
Class Description
Represents a general, dense, square or rectangular matrix.
Represents an upper or lower-triangular matrix, a matrix whose elements below or above the main diagonal are zero.
Represents a square matrix whose elements are symmetrical around the main diagonal.
Note that the specialized classes exploit certain structural properties to perform many calculations more quickly than the general algorithms implemented by .
provides an indexer property. For convenient access to the rows or columns of a or parts thereof, use the and methods.
Overloaded versions of the major arithmetic operators are provided for languages that support them. For languages that don't support operator overloading, equivalent methods are supplied.
Many matrix decompositions exist, serving a variety of purposes. Each of them has its own class. In this release the LU decomposition and the QR decomposition are supported. For positive-definite symmetric matrices, the is available.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleMatrix.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.
This overload of the method stores elements in elementOrder.
member.exception: Always thrown.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of this .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred. Use the method to get the exact condition number.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleMatrix.GetConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates the condition number of this .
member.returns: The condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Calculating the singular values is an expensive operation. The method is faster, but returns an approximation to the condition number.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.returns: true if the matrix is singular; otherwise false.
member.remarks:

A singular matrix does not have an inverse, and a system of simultaneous linear equation corresponding to the matrix does not have a unique solution.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleMatrix.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the QR decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleMatrix.NonzeroComponents
member.summary: Gets a collection of the nonzero components of the matrix.
member.remarks:
Use this property to enumerate over the nonzero components of a sparse matrix. The object that is returned implements . Use this object's method to get access to the elements.
The elements of the enumeration are of type . These are triplets consisting of the row, the column and the value of the nonzero component.
Note to implementors: the order in which the components are enumerated is not specified. However, you must ensure that, before a component is yielded, all components with smaller row or column index have already been enumerated.

member.summary: Represents a column in a .
member.remarks:
is the default implementation of a vector that represents a column or part of a column in a . It is the type returned by the method of the class.
If you define your own matrix class, which should inherit from , you may want to define your own vector type to take advantage of structural properties of the matrix.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleVector
member.summary: Represents a vector, a one-dimensional array of real numbers.
member.remarks:
The class represents a one-dimensional array of float precision floating-point numbers.
The class provides methods and properties for all the common operations on vectors, including norms, dot products, as well as retrieving extreme values from a vector.
Overloaded versions of the major arithmetic operators are provided for languages that support them. For languages that don't support operator overloading, equivalent methods are supplied.
To allow for greater efficiency, overloaded instance methods are available for many compound operations on vectors.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleVector.CloneData
member.summary: If possible, gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a vector that is a view on a column in the matrix. Changing an element in the vector changes the corresponding element in the matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleVector.InverseFourierTransform(Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplexVector)
member.summary: Returns the inverse Fourier transform of a vector.
member.param: A .
member.returns: A containing the inverse Fourier transform of .
member.exception: is
member.remarks:
This method returns the real part of the inverse transform. If the length of is odd, then only the first half of is used in the calculation.
The Fourier transform of a real vector has a certain symmetry: it is equal to the conjugate of the same vector with its elements in reverse order. If does not have this symmetry, then the inverse transform has a nonzero imaginary part, and this method will return a wrong or incomplete result. Use the to obtain the full, complex inverse Fourier transform of a complex vector.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandMatrix.ToGeneralBandMatrix
member.summary: Makes a copy of this instance and returns it as a general .
member.returns: A that is a copy of this .
member.remarks: The method converts a symmetric band matrix into a general band matrix. Only the components on and above the main diagonal of a symmetric band matrix are stored. This method constructs a band matrix that also stores the components below the main diagonal.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandMatrix.ToGeneralBandMatrix(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes a copy of this instance and returns it as a general .
member.param: A that indicates whether to allocate extra storage for a subsequent LU decomposition.
member.returns: A that is a copy of this .
member.remarks:
This method has two primary uses. The first is to convert a symmetric band matrix into a general band matrix. Only the components on and above the main diagonal of a symmetric band matrix are stored. This method constructs a band matrix that also stores the components below the main diagonal.
The second use is to create a matrix suitable for computing an LU decomposition. The upper triangular part of an LU decomposition has a larger bandwidth than the original matrix. In order to calculate the LU decomposition, sufficient space must be allocated for these extra nonzero components.

member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.
This overload of the method stores elements in elementOrder.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleBandVector
member.summary: Represents a vector that has one or more zero components at the beginning and/or at the end.
member.remarks:
Use the class to represent a vector with zero components at the beginning or at the end. The name derives from the fact that the rows and columns of a band matrix have this form.
Many of the standard methods for vectors have been optimized to take advantage of this special structure.
The and specify the index of the first and last non-zero element. These values must be specified in the constructor. Components with an index less than or greater than cannot be modified. Any attempt to do so will result in a . You can verify if a component can be modified by calling the method.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleCholeskyDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the Cholesky decomposition of a positive-definite .
member.remarks:
The Cholesky decomposition of a real symmetric positive definite matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= LLT, where L is a lower-triangular matrix.
can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten with the result of the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations where the matrix of the system is symmetric and positive definite. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant the inverse, and an estimate for the condition number.
To solve a general (non-symmetric or non-positive definite)system of equations, use the class instead.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleCholeskyDecomposition.#ctor(Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricMatrix)
member.summary: Constructs a new object.
member.param: The that is to be factorized. This matrix must be positive-definite, or the decomposition will fail.
member.remarks:
By default, the matrix is preserved. It may be more efficient to overwrite the components of with the result of the decomposition. To do this, set the property to false immediately after creating the .
The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

member.summary: Constructs a new object.
member.param: The that is to be factorized. This matrix must be positive-definite, or the decomposition will fail.
If false, the matrix is preserved. (This is the default.) If true, the matrix is destroyed by the decomposition.
member.remarks: The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleCholeskyDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Performs the actual Cholesky decomposition.
member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.
This method uses the LAPACK routine DPOTRF.
member.exception: The matrix is not positive definite.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleCholeskyDecomposition.TryDecompose
member.summary: Attempts to perform the actual Cholesky decomposition.
member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until or is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.
Unlike , this method does not throw an exception when the matrix is not positive definite. Instead, a value of is returned.
This method uses the LAPACK routine DPOTRF.
member.value: if the decomposition was successful; otherwise .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleCholeskyDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the factorized .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices.
For a Cholesky factorized matrix A = GTG, the determinant is the square of the product of the diagonal elements of G.
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleCholeskyDecomposition.GetInverse
member.summary: Calculates the inverse of the factorized .
member.returns: A that is the inverse matrix of the base matrix of this decomposition.
member.remarks:
The inverse of a matrix is the matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, gives an identity matrix.
If the matrix is singular, its inverse does not exist and a is thrown.
This method uses the LAPACK routine DPOTRI.
member.exception: The matrix is singular.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleCholeskyDecomposition.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the decomposed .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .
This method uses the LAPACK routine DPOCON.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleCholeskyDecomposition.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Sparse.SingleSparseCompressedColumnMatrix
member.summary: Represents a sparse matrix in Compressed Sparse Column format.
member.remarks:
Use the class to represent sparse matrices. Only the nonzero components of the matrix are stored. This not only saves memory, but also allows many calculations to be performed faster.
The compressed sparse column format stores the components in column-major order. Within each column, only the row indexes and the values of the nonzero components are stored.
The components of a sparse matrix can be specified in a variety of ways. A common method is to supply the rows, columns, and values of the nonzero components. Another way is to build up the matrix using the Insert methods: , , , , . Individual components can also be set, but this is generally less efficient.
Sparse matrices can also be read directly from data files in Matrix Market format. Use the for this purpose.
The property returns the number of nonzero components. The property returns a number between 0 and 1 that is the proportion of nonzero components to the total number of components in the matrix. To iterate through the nonzero components of a sparse matrix, use the property. This property enumerates objects, each containing the row, column, and value of a nonzero component.
A disadvantage of sparse matrices is that working with individual components tends to be slower. Every access usually requires a lookup in a list. To avoid duplicate lookups for elementary operations on components, use one of the specialized methods: , , and .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSparseMatrix
member.summary: Represents a sparse matrix.
member.remarks:
Use the class to represent matrices with only a small proportion of nonzero components. Only the nonzero components of the matrix are stored. This not only saves memory, but also allows many calculations to be performed faster.
The components of a sparse matrix can be specified in a variety of ways. A common method is to supply the rows, columns, and values of the nonzero components. Another way is to build up the matrix using the Insert methods: , , , , . Individual components can also be set, but this is generally less efficient.
Sparse matrices can also be read directly from data files in Matrix Market format. Use the for this purpose.
The property returns the number of nonzero components. The property returns a number between 0 and 1 that is the proportion of nonzero components to the total number of components in the matrix. To iterate through the nonzero components of a sparse matrix, use the property. This property enumerates objects, each containing the row, column, and value of a nonzero component.
A disadvantage of sparse matrices is that working with individual components tends to be slower. Every access usually requires a lookup in a list. To avoid duplicate lookups for elementary operations on components, use one of the specialized methods: , , and .
The class is an abstract base class for all types that represent sparse matrices. The class cannot be instantiated. Instead, create instances of one of its derived types:
Class Description
SingleSparseCompressedColumnMatrix Represents a sparse matrix in Compressed Sparse Column (CSC) format, sometimes also called Compressed Column Storage (CCS).

member.summary: Gets a value that indicates the structure of the .
member.remarks:
The possible values for this property are listed below.
Value Description
General The matrix does not have a specific structure.
Symmetric The matrix is symmetric.
Hermitian The complex matrix is hermitian.
Triangular The matrix is triangular.
SkewSymmetric The matrix is skew-symmetric or anti-symmetric.
Diagonal The matrix is a diagonal matrix.

The matrix returned by this method shares its component storage with the original matrix. To give the return value its own copy of the components, call its method.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Sparse.SingleSparseCompressedColumnMatrix.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.
This overload of the method stores elements in elementOrder.
