member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleConstantMatrix.IsSingular
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this matrix is singular.
member.returns: true if the matrix is singular; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
A matrix is singular when its rows or columns are not linearly independent.
A singular matrix does not have an inverse, and a system of simultaneous linear equation corresponding to the matrix does not have a unique solution.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleConstantMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of this .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. For a diagonal matrix, the condition number is very easy to calculate. It is the ratio of the largest to the smallest diagonal element. This method returns the exact condition number, not just an estimate.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleConstantMatrix.GetConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of this .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. For a diagonal matrix, the condition number is very easy to calculate. It is the ratio of the largest to the smallest diagonal element.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleConstantMatrix.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the QR decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDenseMatrix
member.summary: Represents a general, dense, square or rectangular .
member.remarks:
A matrix is a two-dimensional array of real numbers. Use the class to represent general, dense matrices. It is the most general implementation of the class. No components are assumed to have a specific value, and no relationship is assumed to exist between different components.
The components of a are stored in a one-dimensional array of values. By default, components that are adjacent in a column of the matrix are adjacent in the storage array. The components are said to be stored in column major order. It is also possible to have elements stored in row major order.
The class implements algorithms using the general matrix BLAS and LAPACK routines. These routines assume matrix components are stored in column major order. However, any necessary conversions are performed transparantly. No additional work is needed. In some cases there might be a small performance penalty.
Because can represent any matrix, it is often used as the return type of matrix operations.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDenseMatrix.MultiplyByTranspose
member.summary: Multiplies this by its .
member.returns: A that is the product of this with its transpose.
member.remarks:
Some applications, for example the solution of a least squares problem using normal equations, require the product of a matrix with its own transpose. This method performs this operation.
The resulting matrix is always symmetrical and positive definite. This is why a is returned, rather than a more general .
This method uses the BLAS routine DSYRK.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDenseVector
member.summary: Represents a vector with arbitrary components.
member.remarks:
The class represents a one-dimensional array of float-precision floating-point numbers.
The class provides methods and properties for all the common operations on vectors, including norms, dot products, as well as retrieving extreme values from a vector.
Overloaded versions of the major arithmetic operators are provided for languages that support them. For languages that don't support operator overloading, equivalent methods are supplied.
To allow for greater efficiency, overloaded instance methods are available for many compound operations on vectors.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDenseVector.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a vector that is a view on a column in the matrix. Changing an element in the vector changes the corresponding element in the matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDiagonalMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of this .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. For a diagonal matrix, the condition number is very easy to calculate. It is the ratio of the largest to the smallest diagonal element. This method returns the exact condition number, not just an estimate.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleEigenvalueDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the eigenvalue decomposition of a .
member.remarks:
The eigenvalue decomposition of a real square general matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= XLX-1, where X is a matrix and L is a diagonal matrix. The diagonal elements of L are the eigenvalues. The columns of X are the corresponding eigenvectors.
The eigenvalues are either real or come in complex conjugate pairs. The eigenvectors corresponding to real eigenvalues are also real. The eigenvectors corresponding to pairs of complex conjugate eigenvalues are themselves complex conjugates.
The eigenvalues of a real symmetric matrix are always real, and its eigenvectors are orthogonal. Its eigenvalue decomposition can be calculated more easily. This is implemented by the class.
inherits from . However, unlike the other decompositions, the nonsymmetric eigenvalue decomposition does not offer a speed advantage when performing calculations most calculations. For example, solving an equation using the eigen decomposition itself requires the solution of a system of equations. For this reason, the , and methods simply call the corresponding method on the base matrix.

member.summary: Constructs a new object.
member.param: The that is to be factorized. This matrix must be positive-definite, or the decomposition will fail.
member.remarks:
By default, the matrix is preserved. It may be more efficient to overwrite the components of with the result of the decomposition. To do this, set the property to false immediately after creating the .
The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

For an eigenvalue decomposition the magnitude of the determinant is the product of the eigenvalues.

member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleKernel
member.summary: Encapsulates the currently active BLAS implementation.
member.remarks:
The classes in the namespace use the standard Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines (BLAS) whenever possible. The Extreme Optimization Mathematics Library for .NET provides two implementations. One is in 100% managed code. The other calls a native, highly optimized, processor-specific kernel.
This class exposes static properties that allow you to specify the BLAS objects that are to be used by the classes in this namespace.
You can select the managed implementation by calling the method. To select the native implementation, call the method. The native kernel is used by default. This is the fastest option, especially for larger matrices, but also has a larger memory footprint.
Alternatively, you can plug in platform optimized versions by inheriting from the , , and abstract base classes. You can then supply an instance of your class or classes as parameters to the method.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLeastSquaresSolver
member.summary: Represents the solution to a least squares problem.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLeastSquaresSolver.Solve
member.summary: Solves the least squares problem and returns the least norm solution.
member.returns: A single-precision vector containing the least norm solution to the least squares problem.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLeastSquaresSolver.#ctor(Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDenseMatrix,Extreme.Mathematics.SingleVector)
member.summary: Constructs a new from the matrix of observations and the vector of outcomes.
member.param: A whose rows contain the observations of the least squares problem.
A single-precision vector containing the outcomes of each of the observations in .
member.remarks:
Use this constructor to create a least squares solution based on the matrix of observations and the vector of outcomes. The number of rows in must equal the number of elements in . In addition, the number of rows in must be greater than or equal to the number of columns.
Each row in the matrix corresponds to an observation. The corresponding element of the vector specifies the outcome produced by this observation.
Because there are at least as many equations as there are unknowns, an exact solution is not possible. The goal is therefore to minimize the two-norm of the residual vector Ax - b, where A corresponds to and b corresponds to . The vector x with this property is the solution to this problem with minimal norm.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLUDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the LU decomposition of a general .
member.remarks:
The LU decomposition of a matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= PLU, where P is a permutation matrix, L is a unit lower-triangular matrix, and U is an upper-triangular matrix.
can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten by the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant, the inverse, and an estimate for the .

member.overloads: Constructs a new object.
member.summary: Constructs a new object.,
member.param: The that is to be factorized.
member.remarks:
By default, the matrix will be overwritten by its decomposition. You can preserve the original matrix by setting the property to true immediately after creating the .
The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

member.summary: Constructs a new object.
member.param: The that is to be factorized.
If false, the matrix is preserved. (This is the default.) If true, the matrix is destroyed by the decomposition.
member.remarks: The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLUDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Performs the actual LU decomposition.
member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLUDecomposition.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLUDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the decomposed .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
For a LU factorized matrix PA = LU, the determinant is the product of the diagonal elements of U. Since L is defined to be unit triangular, so the product of its diagonal elements equals 1.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.

member.summary: Calculates the inverse of the factorized .
member.returns: A that is the inverse of the matrix.
member.remarks:
The inverse of a matrix is the matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, gives an identity matrix.
If the matrix is singular, its inverse does not exist and a is thrown.
The inverse is only defined for a square matrix. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.
The matrix is singular.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleLUDecomposition.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the matrix underlying this system of equations.
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleMatrixView.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
When a is first created, it reflects the data of the underlying matrix. Changing an element in the matrix view changes the corresponding element in the underlying matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.
Use of is not recommended for objects. Use the method instead.

member.summary: Represents a permutation matrix.
member.remarks:
Use the class to represent, in compact form, a matrix that can be used to permute the rows or columns of a vector or matrix.
A permutation matrix is an orthogonal matrix that has a 1 at exactly one position on each row or column, and is zero everywhere else.

member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. The condition number of a permutation matrix is always 1.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.

The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleQRDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the QR decomposition of a .
member.remarks:
The QR decomposition of a matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= QR, where Q is an orthogonal matrix, and R is an upper-triangular matrix.
can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten by the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant, the inverse, and an estimate for the .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleQRDecomposition.#ctor(Extreme.Mathematics.SingleMatrix)
member.summary: Constructs a new .
member.param: The that is to be decomposed.
member.remarks:
By default, the matrix will be overwritten by its decomposition. You can preserve the original matrix by setting the property to true immediately after creating the .
The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleQRDecomposition.#ctor(Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleDenseMatrix,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new .
member.param: The that is to be decomposed.
If false, the matrix is preserved. (This is the default.) If true, the matrix is destroyed by the decomposition.
member.remarks: The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleQRDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Calculates the actual QR decomposition.
member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleQRDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the decomposed .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
For a QR factorized matrix A = QR, the magnitude of the determinant is the product of the diagonal elements of R. Since Q is orthogonal, its determinant is 1 or -1.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.

member.summary: Calculates the inverse of the factorized .
member.returns: A that is the matrix inverse of this instance.
member.remarks:
The inverse of a matrix is the matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, gives an identity matrix.
If the matrix is singular, its inverse does not exist and a is thrown.
The inverse is only defined for a square matrix. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleQRDecomposition.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleQRDecomposition.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSingularValueDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the singular value decomposition of a matrix.
member.remarks:
The singular value decomposition (SVD) of a matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= USVT, where U and V are orthogonal matrices, and S is a diagonal matrix whose diagonal contains the singular values of the matrix.
can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten by the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant, the inverse, and an estimate for the .
In addition, the class provides some unique methods. The method calculates the pseudo-inverse of the matrix. This is a matrix A+ such that AA+A = A.
The managed implementation of the singular value decomposition is based on the LINPACK routine DSVDC. The native version uses the LAPACK routine DGESDD.

member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSingularValueDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the decomposed .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
For a singular value decomposition A = USVT, the magnitude of the determinant is the product of the diagonal elements of S. Since U and V are orthogonal, their determinant is 1 or -1. This means that only the magnitude of the determinant is known, not its sign.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSingularValueDecomposition.RequestedFactors
member.summary: Gets or sets which factors of the singular value decomposition should be calculated.
member.remarks:
Computing the singular value decomposition of a matrix is a relatively expensive operation. Not all applications require the full decomposition. By specifying which factors are required, significant time can be saved during the calculation.
The singular values are always computed. The calculation of the left and right singular vectors is optional.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSingularValueDecomposition.SingularValues

member.remarks: The singular values are returned in descending order.

member.summary: Gets a matrix with the singular values on the diagonal.
member.remarks: This property returns the matrix S in the decomposition A= USVT. The diagonal matrix has the same number of rows and columns as the base matrix.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSingularValueDecomposition.LeftSingularVectors

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSingularValueDecomposition.RightSingularVectors
member.summary: Gets the right singular vectors of the decomposition.
member.remarks:
This property returns the matrix V in the decomposition A= USVT.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSparseLUDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the LU decomposition of a general .
member.remarks:
The LU decomposition of a matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= PLU, where P is a permutation matrix, L is a unit lower-triangular matrix, and U is an upper-triangular matrix.
can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten by the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant, the inverse, and an estimate for the .

member.overloads: Constructs a new object.
member.summary: Constructs a new object.,
member.param: The that is to be factorized.
member.remarks:
By default, the matrix will be overwritten by its decomposition. You can preserve the original matrix by setting the property to true immediately after creating the .
The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSparseLUDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Performs the actual LU decomposition.
member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSparseLUDecomposition.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSparseLUDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the decomposed .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
For a LU factorized matrix PA = LU, the determinant is the product of the diagonal elements of U. Since L is defined to be unit triangular, so the product of its diagonal elements equals 1.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSparseLUDecomposition.GetInverse
member.summary: Calculates the inverse of the factorized .
member.returns: A that is the inverse of the matrix.
member.remarks:
The inverse of a matrix is the matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, gives an identity matrix.
If the matrix is singular, its inverse does not exist and a is thrown.
The inverse is only defined for a square matrix. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
member.exception: The matrix is not square.
The matrix is singular.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSparseLUDecomposition.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the matrix underlying this system of equations.
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.summary: If possible, gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a vector that is a view on a column in the matrix. Changing an element in the vector changes the corresponding element in the matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricEigenvalueDecomposition
member.summary: Represents the symmetric eigenvalue decomposition of a .
member.remarks:
The symmetric eigenvalue decomposition of a real symmetric matrix A rewrites the matrix in the form A= XLX-1, where X is an orthogonal matrix and L is a diagonal matrix.
can operate in two modes. In overwrite mode, the original matrix is overwritten with the result of the decomposition. In preserve mode, the original matrix is preserved, and a new matrix is created to hold the decomposition. You can set the mode through the property.
inherits from . This means you can use it to solve systems of linear equations where the matrix of the system is symmetric and positive definite. You can solve for a single right-hand side, or for multiple right-hand sides using the method. You can also calculate the determinant the inverse, and an estimate for the condition number.
To solve a general (non-symmetric or non-positive definite)system of equations, use the class instead.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricEigenvalueDecomposition.#ctor(Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricMatrix)
member.summary: Constructs a new object.
member.param: The that is to be factorized. This matrix must be positive-definite, or the decomposition will fail.
member.remarks:
By default, the matrix is preserved. It may be more efficient to overwrite the components of with the result of the decomposition. To do this, set the property to false immediately after creating the .
The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.
member.exception: is .

member.summary: Constructs a new object.

If false, the matrix is preserved. (This is the default.) If true, the matrix is destroyed by the decomposition.
member.remarks: The decomposition isn't performed until it is needed. You can force the calculation to take place by calling the method.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricEigenvalueDecomposition.Decompose
member.summary: Calculates the actual eigenvalue decomposition.
member.remarks:
The decomposition isn't calculated until it is needed. When needed, it is called automatically. You never have to call explicitly unless you want to control when the decomposition is performed.
Until is called, either explicitly or implicitly by one of its methods or properties, you can set the property to specify whether to overwrite or preserve the original matrix.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricEigenvalueDecomposition.GetDeterminant
member.summary: Calculates the determinant of the decomposed .
member.returns: The determinant of the matrix.
The determinant of the matrix.
member.remarks:
A system of simultaneous linear equations has a unique solution if its determinant is not equal to zero.
Determinants are only defined for square matrices. If the matrix is not square, an exception of type is thrown.
For an eigenvalue decomposition the magnitude of the determinant is the product of the eigenvalues.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricEigenvalueDecomposition.GetInverse
member.summary: Calculates the inverse of the factorized .
member.returns: A that is the matrix inverse of this instance.
member.remarks:
The inverse of a matrix is the matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, gives an identity matrix.
If the matrix is singular, its inverse does not exist and a is thrown.
member.exception: The matrix is singular.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricEigenvalueDecomposition.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricEigenvalueDecomposition.Rank(System.Single)
member.overloads: Returns the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.summary: Returns the numerical rank of a matrix using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The absolute tolerance used to determine if a matrix component is considered zero.
member.returns: An integer indicating the numerical rank of the matrix.
member.remarks: If is negative, the default tolerance is used. The default tolerance is equal to the product of the machine precision, the largest dimension of the matrix, and the one-norm of the matrix. The rank is determined by counting the number of diagonal elements of the upper-triangular component of the decomposition whose absolute value is greater than the tolerance.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricMatrix
member.summary: Represents a that is symmetrical about the main diagonal.
member.remarks:
Use the class to represent dense matrices whose elements are symmetrical about the main diagonal. Symmetric matrices are always square.
The components of a are stored in a one-dimensional array of values. Thanks to the symmetry, only the upper or lower-triangular portion needs to be stored.
Symmetric matrices can be constructed from scratch, or they can be derived or extracted from the upper or lower triangular portion of a using one of the methods.
The class implements algorithms using the symmetric matrix BLAS and LAPACK routines. Symmetric matrices are always stored in column-major order.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleSymmetricMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of the .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleTriangularMatrix
member.summary: Represents a whose elements above or below the main diagonal are zero.
member.remarks:
Use the class to represent dense matrices whose elements above or below the diagonal are zero. The name is derived from the shape of the non-zero elements, which form a triangle. However, this class also represents rectangular matrices, whose non-zero elements may form a trapezoid.
A can be either upper or lower-triangular, depending on which components are non-zero. This property is available as the property. It is of type , and must be specified at construction.
Sometimes, the components on the diagonal are all equal to one. In this case, the matrix is said to be unit-diagonal, and the property will be true. Once again, this must be specified at the time the matrix is constructed.
Only the non-zero components of a triangular matrix can be modified. The diagonal components of a unit-diagonal matrix can't be modified. An attempt to do so will result in an . You can verify if a component can be modified by calling the method.
The components of a are stored in a one-dimensional array of values. By default, components that are adjacent in a column of the matrix are adjacent in the storage array. The components are said to be stored in column major order. It is also possible to have elements stored in row major order.
Triangular matrices can be constructed from scratch, or they can be derived or extracted from a using one of the or methods.
The rows and column vectors of a triangular matrix are of type .
The class implements algorithms using the triangular matrix BLAS and LAPACK routines. These routines assume matrix components are stored in column major order. However, any necessary conversions are performed transparantly. No additional work is needed. In some cases there might be a small performance penalty.
objects are used as properties of many matrix decompositions. Both factors of the LU decomposition are triangular. So is at least one factor of the Cholesky Decomposition and the QR Decomposition.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleTriangularMatrix.IsSingular
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the is singular.
member.returns: true if the matrix is singular; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
A matrix is singular when its rows or columns are not linearly independent. For a triangular matrix, this occurs when one of the elements on the diagonal is zero.
A singular matrix does not have an inverse, and a system of simultaneous linear equation corresponding to the matrix does not have a unique solution.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleTriangularMatrix.EstimateConditionNumber
member.summary: Calculates an estimate for the condition number of this .
member.returns: An estimate for the condition number of the .
member.remarks:
The condition number of a matrix is defined as the ratio of its largest to its smallest singular value. Because the calculation of singular values is a very expensive operation, an estimate that is cheaper to calculate is usually preferred.
The condition number gives an indication of the worst case loss of precision when solving a system of simultaneous linear equations.
The condition number of a singular matrix is infinite, which is returned as .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleTriangularMatrix.CloneData
member.summary: Gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a that is a view on a part of a matrix. Changing an element in the submatrix changes the corresponding element in the original matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory, in column-major order.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleUnitBandVector
member.summary: Represents a vector that has one or more zero components at the beginning and/or at the end.
member.remarks:
Use the class to represent a vector with zero components at the beginning or at the end. The name derives from the fact that the rows and columns of a band matrix have this form.
Many of the standard methods for vectors have been optimized to take advantage of this special structure.
The and specify the index of the first and last non-zero element. These values must be specified in the constructor. Components with an index less than or greater than cannot be modified. Any attempt to do so will result in a . You can verify if a component can be modified by calling the method.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingleVectorView.CloneData
member.summary: If possible, gives this instance its own copy of its elements.
member.remarks:
Objects derived from or may share an underlying storage structure. For example, the method of the class returns a vector that is a view on a column in the matrix. Changing an element in the vector changes the corresponding element in the matrix.
This method ensures that this instance has its own copy of the data. After a call to this method, any changes to the elements of this will only affect this instance. Moreover, the elements are guaranteed to be in one contiguous block of memory.
Use of is not recommended for objects. Use the method instead.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleComplexConjugateSignalMatrix
member.summary: Represents a complex matrix that is the Fourier transform of a real signal.
member.remarks:
Use the class to represent a complex matrix that results from computing the Fourier transform of real two-dimensional data. Such a matrix shows a conjugate symmetry. The class takes advantage of this symmetry by storing only just over half of the elements.
Care should be taken when modifying the components of a complex conjugate signal matrix. Setting a component also sets the conjugate component. Iterating through the entire matrix to perform an operation may result in performing the operation twice.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFft
member.summary: Represents a discrete one-dimensional Fourier Transform implementation.

remarks.para: Use the class to perform one or more discrete Fourier Transforms of a specific length. An FFT implementation must be created for each length of FFT and domain. The property is an value and can be real or complex. The length is an integer greater than 0. It can be accessed through the method.
Some implementations use unmanaged resources. To ensure that all resources are released properly, you should call the method when you are done with the object.
This class is abstract and cannot be instantiated. Instead, use one of the methods of an to construct an object from that provider.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase
member.summary: Represents a discrete Fourier Transform implementation.

remarks.para: The class serves as the abstract base class for all implementations of a discrete Fourier Transform. Specialized classes, and , have been provided for one and two-dimensional FFT's, respectively. Inherit from these classes to implement a specific one or two-dimensional FFT algorithm.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase.Commit
member.summary: Commits the implementation.
member.remarks: This method commits the implementation to its current parameters. Inheritors can override this method to compute auxiliary values such as twiddle factors. Inheritors should always call the base method. Otherwise, loss of resources may result.

member.summary: Implements the Dispose pattern.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase.Dispose
member.summary: Implements the interface.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase.Dimension
member.summary: Gets or sets the dimension of the FFT.
member.remarks:
Currently, only one-dimensional FFT's are supported.
The lenght of an FFT is fixed at the time of construction. You can get the length of the FFT through the method.
You can only set this value if the implementation is not committed.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase.InPlace
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the transform should be performed in place.
member.remarks:
Not all FFT providers support in-place transforms. In such cases, the behavior is simulated by performing an out-of-place FFT and copying the result to the original input.
You can only set this value if the implementation is not committed.
member.value: if the transform should be performed in place; otherwise .

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase.Domain
member.summary: Gets or sets the domain of the FFT.
member.remarks:
The domain specifies the source domain of the forward transform. It can be real or complex. The destination domain is always complex.
You can only set this value if the implementation is not committed.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase.ForwardScaleFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale factor used in forward transforms.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase.BackwardScaleFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale factor used in forward transforms.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleFftBase.Committed
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the FFT implementation has committed to its current property values.
member.remarks: You can only set the domain, dimension and length of an FFT implementation as long as the implementation is not yet committed. An implementation commits when it is first called to perform a transform.
member.value: if the implementation is committed; otherwise .

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleManagedFftProvider.RealManagedThresholdLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the threshold for switching between the managed and native FFT providers.
member.remarks:
Real transforms of length less than or equal to are always performed using the managed provider. Real transforms of length greater than are performed using a native provider, if one is available.
The default value for the threshold is 64.

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.SignalProcessing.SingleManagedFftProvider.ComplexManagedThresholdLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the threshold for switching between the managed and native FFT providers.
member.remarks:
Complex transforms of length less than or equal to are always performed using the managed provider. Complex transforms of length greater than are performed using a native provider, if one is available.
The default value for the threshold is 32.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex
member.summary: Represents a complex number.
member.remarks:
The value type represents a complex number made of float-precision, 64-bit real and imaginary parts.
SingleComplex numbers arise in algebra in the solution of quadratic equations. The equation x2= 1 does not have any real solutions. However, if we define a new number, i as the square root of -1, then we have two solutions: i and -i.
This, in turn, gives rise to an entirely new class of numbers of the form a + ib with a and b real, and i defined as above. These are the complex numbers.
The structure provides methods for all the common operations on complex numbers. The property returns the real component of the complex number, while returns the imaginary part. Because the complex numbers don't have a natural ordering, only equality and inequality operators are available.
Overloaded versions of the major arithmetic operators are provided for languages that support them. For languages that don't support operator overloading, equivalent methods are supplied.
When performing binary operations, if one of the operands is a , then the other operand is required to be an integral type or a floating-point type ( or ) or a complex type (). Prior to performing the operation, if the other operand is not a , it is converted to , and the operation is performed using at least float precision. If the operation produces a numeric result, the type of the result is .
Exceptions to this are methods that return a real property of a complex number: , , and . These methods return a value.
The floating-point operators, including the assignment operators, do not throw exceptions. Instead, in exceptional situations, the result of a floating-point operation is zero, , or , as described below:
If the result of a complex floating-point operation is too small for the destination format, the result of the operation is zero.
If the magnitude of the complex result of a floating-point operation is too large for the destination format, the result of the operation is . Directed infinities are currently not supported.
If a complex floating-point operation is invalid, the result of the operation is .
If one or both operands of a complex floating-point operation are , the result of the operation is .
Many elementary functions have been extended to the complex domain. These are implemented by static methods.
Some of these functions are multi-valued. If there is one real argument, then any symmetry or anti-symmetry about the origin is preserved. For example, the inverse sine function satisfies asin(-x) == -asin(x) for -1 <= x <= 1. The method satisfies this relationship for any real value of x.
For complex arguments, the identity Conjugate(f(x)) == f(Conjugate(x)) is preserved. The branch cuts for all complex functions defined here are along either the real or the imaginary axis. Along the branch cuts, the functions have different values depending on whether the zero component is normal (positive) zero or negative zero.
The real and imaginary parts of numbers are float-precision floating-point numbers.

member.name: F:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex.NegativeZero
member.summary: Represents negative zero.

member.name: F:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex.I
member.summary: Represents the square root of -1.
member.remarks: This complex number has its real part equal to zero and its imaginary part equal to one.

member.name: F:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex.Zero
member.summary: Represents the complex number zero.
member.remarks: This complex number has its real part and its imaginary part equal to zero.

member.name: F:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex.One
member.summary: Represents the complex number one.
member.remarks: This complex number has its real part equal to one and its imaginary part equal to zero.

member.name: F:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex.NaN
member.summary: Represents complex NaN, or Not a Number.
member.remarks:
This constant is returned when the result of an operation is undefined.
is returned when the result of a floating-point operation involving complex numbers is undefined. Use to determine whether a value is not a number. It is not possible to determine whether a value is not a number by comparing it to another value equal to .

member.name: F:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex.Infinity
member.summary: Represents complex infinity.
member.remarks:
SingleComplex infinity does not have a sign. Because the complex numbers do not have a natural ordering, it does not make sense to speak of positive or negative numbers.
Directed infinities, where the is infinite, but the is finite, are not supported in this release.
is returned when the magnitude of the complex result of a floating-point operation is too large for the destination format. Use to determine whether a value is infinite.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a complex number from rectangular or polar components.
member.param: If is true, specifies the modulus of the complex number. If is false, specifies the real part.
If is true, specifies the argument of the complex number. If is false, specifies the imaginary part.
Indicates whether the parameters and are for the polar (= true or rectangular (= false) representation.
member.remarks:
A complex number can be defined in two ways.
The standard way is to specify its real and imaginary parts. If is false, the and parameters are interpreted respectively as the real and imaginary components of the complex number.
A complex number can also be specified in polar form. If is true, the parameter is taken to be the modulus, and the parameter is taken to be the argument of the complex number. The corresponding complex number is equal to
cos + i sin .
Note: This constructor has been deprecated. Please use the method instead.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleComplex.RootOfUnity(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a complex number that is the specified root of unity of the specified degree.
member.param: The degree of the root.
The index of the root.
member.returns: A complex number that is the th root of unity of degree .
member.remarks:
The roots of unity are the solutions to the equation zn= 1, with n the degree, which cannot be zero. There are exactly n solutions to this equations. Together, they give the coordinates of a regular n-sided polygon with its center at the origin, its vertices at unit distance from the origin, and its first vertex on the real axis.
This method returns the roots of the specified degree in counter-clockwise order. The index can be any integer value.
member.exception: is equal to zero.

member.param: A number.
member.returns: The natural logarithm of .
member.remarks:
The real component of the logarithm of a complex number is equal to the logarithm of its . The imaginary component of the logarithm of a complex number is equal to the of the complex number. As a result, the imaginary component is only defined up to a multiple of two times . The imaginary component returned by always lies between - and .
This method extends the method of the class to complex numbers.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.SingleInterval
member.summary: Represents an interval of real numbers.
member.remarks:
Use the structure to represent an interval of real numbers. The and properties return the bounds of the interval. The property returns the width of the interval. The method determines whether a value is contained within an interval.
Arithmetic operators are defined for combining intervals. For languages that do not support operator overloading, equivalent methods have been supplied. structures are immutable. The lower and upper bounds can not be changed. Use the constructor or one of the operator methods to create an with new values for the boundaries.

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComparer
member.summary: Represents a comparer for double-precision floating-point numbers with specified tolerance.

remarks.para: Two apparently equivalent floating-point numbers may not compare equal because of differences in their least significant digits. This is usually caused by round-off error resulting from the finite precision of floating-point representations. For example, the C# expression, (double)1/3 == (double)0.33333, does not compare equal because the division operation on the left-hand side has maximum precision while the constant on the right-hand side is only precise to the visible digits.
Instead, determine if the two sides of a comparison are close enough to equal for your purposes. The class lets you specify the tolerance within which two numbers are considered equal.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComparer.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The relative tolerance.

remarks.para: Two numbers are considered equal when the absolute value of their difference is less than the tolerance times the absolute value of the largest of the two numbers.
A common value for the tolerance is around 10 times the machine precision.

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComparer.System#Collections#IComparer#Compare(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Compares two objects and returns a value indicating whether one is less than, equal to or greater than the other.
member.param: The first to compare.
The second to compare.

remarks.para: Two numbers are considered equal if the absolute value of their difference is less than times the larger of the absolute values of and .
The strongly typed method is much more efficient, and should be chosen over this implementation whenever possible.

member.exception: One or both arguments are not of type .

member.name: M:Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComparer.Compare(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compares two values and returns a value indicating whether one is less than, equal to or greater than the other.
member.param: A real number.
A real number.

remarks.para: Two numbers are considered equal if the absolute value of their difference is less than times the larger of the absolute values of and .

member.name: P:Extreme.Mathematics.DoubleComparer.Tolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the relative tolerance within which two numbers compare equal.

remarks.para: Two numbers are considered equal if the absolute value of their difference is less than times the larger of the absolute values of the two numbers.
To be meaningful, the value of this property should be a small number larger than .

member.name: T:Extreme.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Kernel
member.summary: Encapsulates the currently active BLAS implementation.

remarks.para: The classes in the namespace use the standard Basic Linear Algebra Subroutines (BLAS) whenever possible. The Extreme Optimization Mathematics Library for .NET provides two implementations. One is in 100% managed code. The other calls a native, highly optimized, processor-specific kernel.
This class exposes static properties that allow you to specify the BLAS objects that are to be used by the classes in this namespace.

You can select the managed implementation by calling the method. To select the native implementation, call the method. The native kernel is used by default. This is the fastest option, especially for larger matrices, but also has a larger memory footprint.
Alternatively, you can plug in platform optimized versions by inheriting from the , , and abstract base classes. You can then supply an instance of your class or classes as parameters to the method.
